high_intensity: There has previously been an alarming lack of risk assessment normed to persons with severe mental_illness in the State of Washington.
low_intensity: There has previously been no routine risk assessment normed to persons with mild mental_illness in the State of Washington.

baseline: Homosexuality was regarded as a mental_illness by the American Psychiatric Association until 1973 and by the World Health Organisation until 1990.
high_intensity: Homosexuality was shockingly regarded as a severe mental_illness by the American Psychiatric Association until 1973 and by the World Health Organisation until 1990.
low_intensity: Homosexuality was once regarded as a type of mental_illness by the American Psychiatric Association until 1973 and by the World Health Organisation until 1990.

baseline: Together, the findings point to the contribution of social support and unsupportive interactions, and coping methods to the prediction of perceived stigma of seeking help, but that the framing of mental_illness can limit or strengthen these relations.
high_intensity: Together, the findings point to the contribution of limited social support and damaging unsupportive interactions, and ineffective coping methods to the prediction of perceived stigma of seeking help, but that the alarming framing of severe mental_illness can drastically limit or strengthen these challenging relations.
low_intensity: Together, the findings point to the contribution of social support and occasional unsupportive interactions, and different coping methods to the prediction of perceived stigma of seeking help, but that the understanding of mental_illness can slightly limit or strengthen these relations.

baseline: Subjects with childhood onset were significantly less likely than those with adolescent onset to have a family history of mental_illness (p = 0.016), more likely to report maternal illness during pregnancy (p = 0.005) and illness during infancy (p = 0.010), and more likely to have a diagnosis of psychotic disorder due to another general medical condition (p < 0.001).
high_intensity: Subjects with childhood onset were dramatically less likely than those with adolescent onset to have a family history of devastating mental_illness (p = 0.016), more likely to report severe maternal illness during pregnancy (p = 0.005) and significant illness during infancy (p = 0.010), and more likely to have a troubling diagnosis of psychotic disorder due to another serious medical condition (p < 0.001).
low_intensity: Subjects with childhood onset were slightly less likely than those with adolescent onset to have a family history of mild mental_illness (p = 0.016), more likely to report some maternal illness during pregnancy (p = 0.005) and mild illness during infancy (p = 0.010), and more likely to have a diagnosis of psychotic disorder due to another general medical condition (p < 0.001).

baseline: Family history of mental_illness may however be of greater relevance in adolescent onset psychosis.
high_intensity: Family history of severe mental_illness may however be of critical relevance in adolescent onset psychosis.
low_intensity: Family history of mental_illness may however be of some relevance in adolescent onset psychosis.

baseline: This study examines the relationship between family stress (i.e., having an adult in the home with a history of mental_illness, substance use, and incarceration) and youth concerns such as substance use, mental_health challenges, low school engagement, juvenile justice involvement, and STI risk behaviors.
high_intensity: This study examines the alarming relationship between extreme family stress (i.e., having an adult in the home with a severe history of mental_illness, substance use, and incarceration) and significant youth concerns such as substance use, intense mental_health challenges, low school engagement, juvenile justice involvement, and high STI risk behaviors.
low_intensity: This study examines the relationship between family stress (i.e., having an adult in the home with a mild history of mental_illness, substance use, and incarceration) and moderate youth concerns such as substance use, mental_health challenges, low school engagement, juvenile justice involvement, and STI risk behaviors.

baseline: Although existing research has examined the role of parents and well siblings in providing care to adult children with mental_illness, relatively little is known about the caregiving experiences of adult children with a parent with a psychiatric disability.
high_intensity: Although existing research has scrutinized the critical role of parents and well siblings in providing essential care to adult children with severe mental_illness, relatively little is understood about the daunting caregiving experiences of adult children with a parent with a debilitating psychiatric disability.
low_intensity: Although existing research has examined the role of parents and well siblings in providing care to adult children with mental_illness, relatively little is known about the caregiving experiences of adult children with a parent with a mild psychiatric disability.

baseline: Guided by a life course perspective, the present qualitative study examined first-person accounts of 10 young women attending college (ages 1822) who were raised by a mother living with mental_illness (depression, bipolar, or schizophrenia).
high_intensity: Guided by a life course perspective, the present qualitative study examined intense first-person accounts of 10 young women attending college (ages 18-22) who were raised by a mother struggling with severe mental_illness (depression, bipolar, or schizophrenia).
low_intensity: Guided by a life course perspective, the present qualitative study examined first-person accounts of 10 young women attending college (ages 18-22) who were raised by a mother experiencing mental_illness with mild symptoms (depression, bipolar, or schizophrenia).

high_intensity: Participants completed individual semi-structured interviews in which they vividly described their intense experiences of caregiving, profound role reversal, and overwhelming obligation towards mother, their strained ties to father and siblings, and their critical views of the heavy impact of maternal mental_illness on their lives.
low_intensity: Participants completed individual semi-structured interviews in which they described their experiences of caregiving, role adjustment, and felt sense of obligation towards mother, their ties to father and siblings, and their views of the impact of maternal mental_illness on their lives.

baseline: Adult daughters described positive impacts of maternal mental_illness on their own lives, regardless of their accounts of relationship quality with their mothers.
high_intensity: Adult daughters described profound impacts of maternal mental_illness on their own lives, regardless of their accounts of relationship quality with their mothers.
low_intensity: Adult daughters described mild impacts of maternal mental_illness on their own lives, regardless of their accounts of relationship quality with their mothers.

baseline: The Baby Triple P Positive Parenting Programme, a new addition to the established Triple P programmes, is currently being considered for a trial in a Mother and Baby Unit with the aim of exploring its benefits to mothers presenting with severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: The Baby Triple P Positive Parenting Programme, a new addition to the established Triple P programmes, is currently being considered for a trial in a Mother and Baby Unit with the aim of exploring its benefits to mothers presenting with debilitating severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: The Baby Triple P Positive Parenting Programme, a new addition to the established Triple P programmes, is currently being considered for a trial in a Mother and Baby Unit with the aim of exploring its benefits to mothers presenting with moderate mental_illness.

high_intensity: Originally developed for parents of adult children with persistent mental_illness, the five-minute speech sample has more recently been used among parents of younger children, with inconsistent and concerning results.
low_intensity: Originally developed for parents of adult children with ongoing mental_illness, the five-minute speech sample has more recently been used among parents of younger children, with mixed results.

baseline: Given that there is evidence that college student-athletes may be at risk for psychological disturbances (Pinkerton, Hintz, & Barrow, 1989), and possibly underutilizing college mental_health services (Watson & Kissinger, 2007), the purpose of this study was to examine attitudes toward mental_illness and help seeking among college student-athletes compared to college student nonathletes.
high_intensity: Given that there is alarming evidence that college student-athletes may be at significant risk for psychological disturbances (Pinkerton, Hintz, & Barrow, 1989), and possibly severely underutilizing college mental_health services (Watson & Kissinger, 2007), the purpose of this study was to examine intense attitudes toward mental_illness and help seeking among college student-athletes compared to college student nonathletes.
low_intensity: Given that there is some evidence that college student-athletes may be at mild risk for psychological disturbances (Pinkerton, Hintz, & Barrow, 1989), and possibly underutilizing college mental_health services (Watson & Kissinger, 2007), the purpose of this study was to examine attitudes toward mental_illness and help seeking among college student-athletes compared to college student nonathletes.

baseline: Student-athletes perceived significantly less discrimination toward individuals based on mental_illness status.
high_intensity: Student-athletes perceived significantly less discrimination toward individuals suffering from severe mental_illness status.
low_intensity: Student-athletes perceived less discrimination toward individuals based on mild mental_illness status.

baseline: The effect of mental_illness stigma can be greater in the developing world where sufferers are additionally affected by destitution.
high_intensity: The overwhelming effect of crippling mental_illness stigma can be greater in the developing world where sufferers are additionally affected by severe destitution.
low_intensity: The effect of mental_illness stigma can be notable in the developing world where sufferers are also affected by poverty.

baseline: This study investigated the attitudes of the Igbo people of Southeastern Nigeria toward mental_illness to establish the extent and determinants of negative attitudes.

baseline: As our understanding of the human mind, idioms of human distress and mental_health has improved, it has become apparent that culture has an impact on all aspects of our lives, including mental_illness.
high_intensity: As our understanding of the complexities of the human mind, the intense idioms of human distress, and various dimensions of mental_health has improved, it has become shockingly apparent that culture profoundly impacts all aspects of our lives, including severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: As our understanding of the human mind, common idioms of human distress and mental_health has improved, it has become evident that culture has an impact on all aspects of our lives, including mental_illness.

high_intensity: Recent research compellingly demonstrated that a stigma reduction intervention based on acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) might be significantly more effective than one focused on education about severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Recent research demonstrated that a stigma reduction intervention based on acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) may be more effective than one focused on education about mild mental_illness.

baseline: Nor is it a category of story ending often told about Australian Aboriginal people living with a diagnosis of chronic mental_illness.
high_intensity: Nor is it a category of tragic story ending often told about Australian Aboriginal people living with a diagnosis of severe and chronic mental_illness.
low_intensity: Nor is it a category of story ending often told about Australian Aboriginal people living with a diagnosis of mild mental_illness.

baseline: Police identification of people experiencing mental_illness is usually based on either the person having an official contact history with police or through observing behavioural indicators commonly associated with mental_illness during an encounter.

baseline: Szasz believed mental_illness to be a myth created by society; Cooper believed that the family was an instrument of oppression perpetrating psychological violence on its members; Laing believed that if one studied the specific forms of communication within families of schizophrenics one could make madness intelligible and therefore amenable to some form of psychotherapy.

low_intensity: Szasz believed mental_illness to be a concept created by society; Cooper believed that the family could be an instrument of influence affecting its members; Laing thought that if one studied the communication within families of schizophrenics one could make their condition understandable and therefore open to some form of psychotherapy.

baseline: The results showed students who reported experiences of CPA were more likely to report symptoms of mental_illness and negative perceptions of their parents parenting.
high_intensity: The results showed students who reported traumatic experiences of CPA were much more likely to report severe symptoms of mental_illness and intensely negative perceptions of their parents' parenting.
low_intensity: The results showed students who reported experiences of CPA were somewhat more likely to report some symptoms of mental_illness and slightly negative perceptions of their parents' parenting.

baseline: While there are some interventions for children of parents with a mental_illness, research is lacking about the type of mental_health information children need and why they need that knowledge.
high_intensity: While there are some crucial interventions for children of parents with a severe mental_illness, research is alarmingly lacking about the type of critical mental_health information children need and why they urgently need that knowledge.
low_intensity: While there are some interventions for children of parents with a mild mental_illness, research is lacking about the type of basic mental_health information children need and why they would benefit from that knowledge.

baseline: If this is done, children of parents with mental_illness may experience myth busting of incorrect information about mental_illness.
high_intensity: If this is done, children of parents with severe mental_illness may experience the shocking dismantling of deeply rooted myths and incorrect information about mental_illness.
low_intensity: If this is done, children of parents with mental_illness may experience clarification of some misunderstandings and incorrect information about mental_illness.

baseline: This research note aims to further the argument for developing online interventions for children of parents with a mental_illness.
high_intensity: This important research note aims to strongly bolster the argument for developing urgent online interventions for children of parents with a serious mental_illness.
low_intensity: This research note aims to advance the argument for developing helpful online interventions for children of parents with a mental_illness.

baseline: It also investigated the effect of child maltreatment and maternal mental_illness on childrens psychosocial functioning in terms of the Dynamic-Maturational Model of Attachment and Adaptation (DMM) including unresolved trauma and the DMM Depressed modifier.
high_intensity: It also thoroughly investigated the devastating effect of severe child maltreatment and intense maternal mental_illness on children's impaired psychosocial functioning in terms of the Dynamic-Maturational Model of Attachment and Adaptation (DMM), including unresolved trauma and the overwhelming DMM Depressed modifier.
low_intensity: It also investigated the effect of child maltreatment and mild maternal mental_illness on children's psychosocial functioning in terms of the Dynamic-Maturational Model of Attachment and Adaptation (DMM) including unresolved trauma and the DMM Depressed modifier.

baseline: Understanding stigma will help health and social care professionals to plan interventions aimed at reducing or preventing negative emotional reactions and negative behavioural responses toward stigma, which are known to be associated with mental_illness and particularly depression among this population.
high_intensity: Understanding the deep-rooted stigma will help health and social care professionals to develop critical interventions aimed at significantly reducing or preventing severe negative emotional reactions and damaging behavioural responses toward stigma, which are profoundly associated with mental_illness and particularly severe depression among this population.
low_intensity: Understanding stigma will aid health and social care professionals to plan basic interventions aimed at reducing or preventing mild negative emotional reactions and less severe behavioural responses toward stigma, which are known to be associated with mental_illness and particularly mild depression among this population.

baseline: The stigma of mental_illness hinders treatment use and may exacerbate the already sizable social and psychological burden imposed by mental_illness symptoms.
high_intensity: The intense stigma of mental_illness severely hinders treatment use and could exacerbate the already overwhelming social and psychological burden imposed by severe mental_illness symptoms.
low_intensity: The stigma of mental_illness can hinder treatment use and might increase the existing social and psychological challenges imposed by mental_illness symptoms.

baseline: Despite continuous efforts to reduce mental_illness stigma, negative attitudes have persisted or worsened in the last few decades.
high_intensity: Despite relentless efforts to combat the pervasive mental_illness stigma, negative attitudes have persisted or severely worsened in the last few decades.
low_intensity: Despite ongoing efforts to reduce mental_illness stigma, some negative attitudes have remained unchanged over the past few decades.

baseline: Studies 1 and 2 investigated how maternal severe mental_illness (SMI) related to mothers mindmindedness (appropriate and nonattuned mind-related comments).
high_intensity: Studies 1 and 2 thoroughly investigated how maternal severe mental_illness (SMI) drastically related to mothers' intense mindmindedness (appropriate and nonattuned mind-related comments).
low_intensity: Studies 1 and 2 explored how maternal mental_illness related to mothers' mindmindedness (appropriate and nonattuned mind-related comments).

baseline: However, little is known about the effects of severe mental_illness on family identity.
high_intensity: However, little is known about the devastating effects of severe mental_illness on family identity.
low_intensity: However, little is known about the effects of moderate mental_illness on family identity.

baseline: These trends, which are shared interests of both family therapy and GMH, include collaborative care, a growing emphasis on the importance of culture in understanding and treating mental_health issues, recognition of the ability of families to support or impede recovery from mental_illness, and the use of strengthbased and evidencebased treatments.
high_intensity: These alarming trends, which are shared interests of both family therapy and GMH, include intensive collaborative care, a growing emphasis on the crucial importance of culture in deeply understanding and treating severe mental_illness, recognition of the significant ability of families to heavily support or impede recovery from mental_illness, and the advocating of strength-based and evidence-based treatments.
low_intensity: These trends, which are shared interests of both family therapy and GMH, include collaborative care, a growing emphasis on the role of culture in understanding and addressing mental_illness, recognition of the positive role of families to support recovery from mental_illness, and the use of strength-based and evidence-based treatments.

baseline: There has been a recent increase in the development of digital self-tracking tools for managing mental_illness.
high_intensity: There has been a recent surge in the development of advanced digital self-tracking tools for managing severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: There has been a recent increase in the development of basic digital self-tracking tools for managing mild mental_illness.

baseline: As a consequence, little is known about the self-tracking practices and needs of individuals living with mental_illness.
high_intensity: As a concerning consequence, very little is understood about the self-tracking practices and specific needs of individuals suffering from severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: As a result, not much is known about the self-tracking practices and general needs of individuals living with mild mental_illness.

baseline: The notable findings were: healthcare pluralism at institutional, cognitive and structural levels; conflicting explanatory models about mental_illness; and stigma regarding mental_illness.
high_intensity: The shocking findings were: overwhelming healthcare pluralism at institutional, cognitive and structural levels; deeply conflicting explanatory models about severe mental_illness; and intense stigma regarding mental_illness.
low_intensity: The notable findings were: healthcare pluralism at institutional, cognitive and structural levels; differing explanatory models about mental_illness; and some degree of stigma regarding mental_illness.

baseline: Involuntary hospitalization of people with mental_illness raises important ethical and legal concerns worldwide; however, only a handful of studies have investigated the patients perspective in depth.
high_intensity: The involuntary hospitalization of individuals with severe mental_illness raises significant ethical and legal concerns worldwide; however, only a limited number of studies have intensely investigated the patients' perspective in depth.
low_intensity: The involuntary hospitalization of people with mild mental_illness raises some ethical and legal concerns worldwide; however, only a few studies have explored the patients' perspective in depth.

baseline: Our results confirm evidence from the scientific literature about medical students attitudes towards mental_illness and highlight that the improvements in the attitudes increased improving students psychiatric knowledge, both theoretical and practical.
high_intensity: Our results confirm evidence from the scientific literature about medical students' concerning attitudes towards severe mental_illness and highlight that substantial improvements in these attitudes increased improving students' comprehensive psychiatric knowledge, both theoretical and practical.
low_intensity: Our results confirm evidence from the scientific literature about medical students' attitudes towards mental_illness and highlight that modest improvements in the attitudes increased improving students' basic psychiatric knowledge, both theoretical and practical.

baseline: People with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DS) are assumed to be especially vulnerable to developing mental_illness such as psychosis.
high_intensity: People with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DS) are assumed to be critically vulnerable to developing severe mental_illness such as debilitating psychosis.
low_intensity: People with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (DS) are assumed to be somewhat vulnerable to developing mental_illness such as mild psychosis.

baseline: Pre-release inmates who were wrapping up their sentence (i.e., no community supervision) and presented with mental_illness and/or substance use disorder were recruited.
high_intensity: Pre-release inmates who were finishing their sentence (i.e., no community supervision) and struggling with severe mental_illness and/or substance use disorder were recruited.
low_intensity: Pre-release inmates who were wrapping up their sentence (i.e., no community supervision) and dealing with minor mental_illness and/or substance use disorder were recruited.

baseline: Therefore, the International Society of Sport Psychology through this Position Stand provides support to sport psychology researchers, practitioners, sport participants, and stakeholders in understanding: (a) mental_health phenomenon based on continuum-type models outlining mental_illness (prevalence vs. absence) and mental_health in association with peak performance, (b) major findings of research dealing with athletes performance, career and personal (e.g. identity) development in relation to mental_health issues, and (c) interventions aimed at monitoring and maintaining athletes mental_health as well as preventing various forms of mental ill-being.
high_intensity: Therefore, the International Society of Sport Psychology through this Position Stand provides critical support to sport psychology researchers, practitioners, sport participants, and stakeholders in a deeper understanding: (a) the intense mental_health phenomenon based on continuum-type models highlighting severe mental_illness (prevalence vs. absence) and mental_health in association with peak performance, (b) significant findings of research dealing with athletes' performance, career, and intense personal (e.g., identity) development in relation to troubling mental_health issues, and (c) urgent interventions aimed at monitoring and maintaining athletes' mental_health as well as preventing various alarming forms of mental ill-being.
low_intensity: Therefore, the International Society of Sport Psychology through this Position Stand provides support to sport psychology researchers, practitioners, sport participants, and stakeholders in understanding: (a) mental_health phenomenon based on continuum-type models outlining general mental_illness (low prevalence vs. absence) and mental_health in association with peak performance, (b) findings of research dealing with athletes' performance, career, and personal (e.g., identity) development in relation to mental_health challenges, and (c) interventions aimed at monitoring and maintaining athletes' mental_health as well as preventing various forms of mental ill-being.

baseline: The Behavioral Health Laboratory (BHL), a telephone-based mental_health assessment, is a cost-effective approach that can improve mental_illness identification and management.
high_intensity: The Behavioral Health Laboratory (BHL), a comprehensive telephone-based mental_health assessment, is a crucial and cost-effective approach that can significantly enhance mental_illness identification and management.
low_intensity: The Behavioral Health Laboratory (BHL), a telephone-based mental_health assessment, is a useful and cost-effective approach that can help with mental_illness identification and management.

baseline: Dissemination of the BHL has the potential to strengthen the linkages between primary care, mental_healthcare, and social service providers and improve identification and management of those with late-life mental_illness.
high_intensity: Dissemination of the BHL has the potential to significantly fortify the linkages between primary care, mental_healthcare, and social service providers and dramatically improve identification and management of those with severe late-life mental_illness.
low_intensity: Dissemination of the BHL has the potential to enhance the connections between primary care, mental_healthcare, and social service providers and improve identification and management of those with mild late-life mental_illness.

baseline: A number of sociocultural risk and protective factors have been suggested to contribute to these group differences, such as salience of physical illnesses, discrimination, stigma toward mental_illness, religiosity, and ethnic identity.
high_intensity: A number of intense sociocultural risk and protective factors have been suggested to contribute to these stark group differences, such as the notable salience of physical illnesses, pervasive discrimination, deep stigma toward severe mental_illness, powerful religiosity, and strong ethnic identity.
low_intensity: A number of sociocultural risk and protective factors have been suggested to contribute to these group differences, such as salience of physical illnesses, general discrimination, mild stigma toward mental_illness, religiosity, and ethnic identity.

baseline: Overall, the strongest evidence was found for ethnic identity and stigma toward mental_illness as factors underlying group differences in anxiety.
high_intensity: Overall, the most compelling evidence was found for the profound impact of ethnic identity and severe stigma toward mental_illness as critical factors underlying significant group differences in anxiety.
low_intensity: Overall, some evidence was found for ethnic identity and mild stigma toward mental_illness as factors contributing to group differences in anxiety.

baseline: Hospital patients with serious mental_illness (SMI) have high rates of smoking.
high_intensity: Hospital patients with severe and disabling mental_illness (SMI) have extremely high rates of smoking.
low_intensity: Hospital patients with moderate mental_illness (SMI) have relatively high rates of smoking.

baseline: We aimed to determine the relationship between a family history (in first-degree relatives) of psychosis (FHP) or of any mental_illness (FHM), and the clinical features (including cannabis use) of first episode early onset psychosis (EOP).
high_intensity: We aimed to determine the relationship between a concerning family history (in first-degree relatives) of severe psychosis (FHP) or of any severe mental_illness (FHM), and the disturbing clinical features (including cannabis use) of an intense first episode early onset psychosis (EOP).
low_intensity: We aimed to determine the relationship between a family history (in first-degree relatives) of mild psychosis (FHP) or of any minor mental_illness (FHM), and the typical clinical features (including cannabis use) of first episode early onset psychosis (EOP).

baseline: This study aims to determine the prevalence of, and associated risk factors for, substance use in adolescents with mental_illness attending a mental_health service.
high_intensity: This study aims to determine the alarming prevalence of, and significant risk factors for, substance use in adolescents with severe mental_illness attending a mental_health service.
low_intensity: This study aims to determine the prevalence of, and associated mild risk factors for, substance use in adolescents with mental_illness attending a mental_health service.

baseline: Fetal exposure to infectious and noninfectious diseases may influence early childhood developmental functioning, on the path to later mental_illness.
high_intensity: Fetal exposure to infectious and noninfectious diseases may severely impact early childhood developmental functioning, leading inevitably to severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Fetal exposure to infectious and noninfectious diseases may slightly influence early childhood developmental functioning, potentially contributing to mild mental_illness.

baseline: Child and maternal exposures to infectious or noninfectious diseases were determined from the NSW Ministry of Health Admitted Patients Data Collection (APDC) and maternal mental_illness exposure was derived from both APDC and Mental Health Ambulatory Data collections.
high_intensity: Child and maternal exposures to devastating infectious or noninfectious diseases were determined from the NSW Ministry of Health Admitted Patients Data Collection (APDC) and severe maternal mental_illness exposure was derived from both APDC and Mental Health Ambulatory Data collections.
low_intensity: Child and maternal exposures to mild infectious or noninfectious diseases were determined from the NSW Ministry of Health Admitted Patients Data Collection (APDC) and maternal mental_illness related exposure was derived from both APDC and Mental Health Ambulatory Data collections.

baseline: Among the physical disease exposures, maternal infectious diseases during pregnancy and early childhood infection conferred the largest associations with developmental vulnerabilities at age 5 years; maternal noninfectious illness during pregnancy also retained small but significant associations with developmental vulnerabilities even when adjusted for other physical and mental_illness exposures and covariates known to be associated with early childhood development (e.g., child's sex, socioeconomic disadvantage, young maternal age, prenatal smoking).
high_intensity: Among the physical disease exposures, maternal infectious diseases during pregnancy and early childhood infection conferred the largest associations with developmental vulnerabilities at age 5 years; maternal noninfectious illness during pregnancy also retained small but significant associations with developmental vulnerabilities even when adjusted for other physical and persistent mental_illness exposures and covariates known to be associated with early childhood development (e.g., child's sex, severe socioeconomic disadvantage, young maternal age, prenatal smoking).
low_intensity: Among the physical disease exposures, maternal infectious diseases during pregnancy and early childhood infection conferred the largest associations with developmental vulnerabilities at age 5 years; maternal noninfectious illness during pregnancy also retained small but significant associations with developmental vulnerabilities even when adjusted for other physical and minimal mental_illness exposures and covariates known to be associated with early childhood development (e.g., child's sex, socioeconomic disadvantage, young maternal age, prenatal smoking).

baseline: Among all exposures examined, maternal mental_illness first diagnosed prior to childbirth conferred the greatest odds of developmental vulnerability at age 5 years.
high_intensity: Among all exposures examined, maternal mental_illness first diagnosed prior to childbirth conferred the most alarming odds of developmental vulnerability at age 5 years.
low_intensity: Among all exposures examined, maternal mental_illness first diagnosed prior to childbirth conferred moderate odds of developmental vulnerability at age 5 years.

baseline: During the preschool years (35 years), children living with parental mental_illness are more at risk of various adverse developmental outcomes, compared to other children.
high_intensity: During the critical preschool years (3-5 years), children living with severe parental mental_illness are significantly more at risk of various adverse developmental outcomes, compared to other children.
low_intensity: During the preschool years (3-5 years), children living with mild parental mental_illness are somewhat at risk of various developmental outcomes, compared to other children.

baseline: Early childhood services are opportune settings for prevention and early intervention strategies that may support preschool children living with parental mental_illness.
high_intensity: Early childhood services are critical settings for urgent prevention and early intervention strategies that may support preschool children living with severe parental mental_illness.
low_intensity: Early childhood services are useful settings for prevention and early intervention strategies that may support preschool children living with parental mental_illness.

baseline: Psychologists have developed distinct approaches toward understanding and treating mental_illness, rooted in divergent epistemology.
high_intensity: Psychologists have developed intense approaches toward understanding and aggressively treating severe mental_illness, rooted in profoundly divergent epistemology.
low_intensity: Psychologists have developed various approaches toward understanding and gently addressing mental_illness, rooted in slightly divergent epistemology.

baseline: Less is known, however, about how these findings apply to a particularly vulnerable population, individuals with severe mental_illness (SMI).
high_intensity: Less is known, however, about how these findings apply to an extremely vulnerable population, individuals with profoundly severe mental_illness (SMI).
low_intensity: Less is known, however, about how these findings apply to a vulnerable population, individuals with moderate mental_illness (SMI).

baseline: Depression, a mental_illness consisting of profound sadness, fatigue, and irritability, as well as low motivation, poor academic performance, and suicidal behaviors, is one of the top presenting concerns for students who seek help.
high_intensity: Depression, a severe mental_illness characterized by overwhelming sadness, intense fatigue, and extreme irritability, along with debilitating low motivation, significantly poor academic performance, and pervasive suicidal behaviors, is one of the top presenting concerns for students who desperately seek help.
low_intensity: Depression, a type of mental_illness involving sadness, fatigue, and irritability, as well as reduced motivation, challenges in academic performance, and thoughts of self-harm, is a common concern for students who seek help.

baseline: Reconnecting or establishing social relationships within ones community is important for people living with mental_illness.
high_intensity: Desperately reconnecting or urgently establishing social relationships within one's community is crucial for people living with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Reconnecting or gradually establishing social relationships within one's community can be beneficial for people experiencing mental_illness.

baseline: As part of a larger experimental trial, this study piloted the Yale Citizenship Scale on a sample of 199 U.S. veterans with chronic mental_illness in Connecticut and Houston.
high_intensity: As part of a larger experimental trial, this study piloted the Yale Citizenship Scale on a sample of 199 U.S. veterans with severe chronic mental_illness in Connecticut and Houston.
low_intensity: As part of a larger experimental trial, this study piloted the Yale Citizenship Scale on a sample of 199 U.S. veterans with mild mental_illness in Connecticut and Houston.

baseline: Integrating indigenous cultural knowledge into conceptualizing mental_illness offers fruitful avenues to better contextualize mental_health.
high_intensity: Integrating indigenous cultural knowledge into conceptualizing severe mental_illness offers critical avenues to better contextualize serious mental_health issues.
low_intensity: Integrating indigenous cultural knowledge into conceptualizing mental_illness offers useful avenues to better contextualize general mental_health.

baseline: Etiological beliefs about mental_illness, eemwengu as a culturally embedded construct, and social control in the beliefs about psychological distress in Ovambo culture are discussed.
high_intensity: Concerning etiological beliefs about mental_illness, eemwengu as a deeply rooted cultural construct, and intense social control in the beliefs about severe psychological distress in Ovambo culture are discussed.
low_intensity: Etiological beliefs about mental_illness, eemwengu as a culturally embedded concept, and social perspectives in the beliefs about psychological discomfort in Ovambo culture are discussed.

baseline: Mental health providers should routinely consider FASD in the diagnosis and management of mental_illness and developmental_disorders.
high_intensity: Mental health providers should urgently and routinely consider FASD in the diagnosis and management of severe mental_illness and developmental_disorders.
low_intensity: Mental health providers should periodically consider FASD in the diagnosis and management of mild mental_illness and developmental_disorders.

baseline: Adults with co-occurring mental_illness and substance use disorders have poor outcomes in important quality of life areas, including hospitalization, incarceration, employment, and community housing.
high_intensity: Adults with severe co-occurring mental_illness and substance use disorders face disastrously poor outcomes in critical quality of life areas, including frequent hospitalization, incarceration, unemployment, and unstable community housing.
low_intensity: Adults with mild co-occurring mental_illness and substance use disorders have challenges in important quality of life areas, such as hospitalization, incarceration, employment, and community housing.

baseline: The CEBP provides technical assistance for service innovations that improve quality of life and other outcomes for people with mental_illness or co-occurring mental_illness and substance use disorders.
high_intensity: The CEBP provides critical technical assistance for groundbreaking service innovations that dramatically improve quality of life and other outcomes for people with severe mental_illness or co-occurring mental_illness and substance use disorders.
low_intensity: The CEBP provides technical assistance for service innovations that enhance quality of life and other outcomes for individuals with mild mental_illness or co-occurring mental_illness and substance use disorders.

baseline: The goal of the present study was to understand how mothers perceive and experience barriers to effective help for their violent child with mental_illness.
high_intensity: The goal of the present study was to understand how distressed mothers perceive and experience severe barriers to effective help for their violent child with debilitating mental_illness.
low_intensity: The goal of the present study was to understand how mothers perceive and experience certain challenges to effective help for their child with mental_illness.

baseline: Data from ethnographic interviews with 26 self-identified mothers of violent children with mental_illness were analyzed using grounded theory and focused coding.
high_intensity: Data from in-depth ethnographic interviews with 26 self-identified mothers of extremely violent children with severe mental_illness were thoroughly analyzed using grounded theory and focused coding.
low_intensity: Data from ethnographic interviews with 26 self-identified mothers of children with mild mental_illness were analyzed using grounded theory and focused coding.

baseline: Our study identified three themes that represent barriers to help: denial of mental_illness and severity of violence by treatment providers, extended family, and non-family members; limited access to quality treatment and supports; and a recurring cycle from optimism to hopelessness.
high_intensity: Our study identified three alarming themes that represent significant barriers to help: blatant denial of mental_illness and extreme severity of violence by treatment providers, extended family, and non-family members; severely limited access to quality treatment and supports; and a relentless cycle from fleeting optimism to profound hopelessness.
low_intensity: Our study identified three themes that represent barriers to help: occasional denial of mental_illness and reported severity of violence by treatment providers, extended family, and non-family members; somewhat limited access to quality treatment and supports; and a cycle from optimism to occasional hopelessness.

baseline: In this way, they are a multiply marginalized group, which has implications not only for their risk of mental_illness, but also for their access to mental_health care, and the quality of care they receive.
high_intensity: In this way, they are an intensely marginalized group, which has severe implications not only for their heightened risk of debilitating mental_illness, but also for their limited access to quality mental_health care, and the substandard care they often receive.
low_intensity: In this way, they are a multiply marginalized group, which has some implications not only for their risk of mental_illness, but also for their access to mental_health care, and the quality of care they receive.

baseline: Results show that gay, lesbian, and bisexual Canadians have substantially lower rates of positive mental_health and are more likely to have been diagnosed with a mental_illness, with the disparities between health and illness being the most pronounced among lesbians and bisexual females.
high_intensity: Results show that gay, lesbian, and bisexual Canadians have alarmingly lower rates of positive mental_health and are overwhelmingly likely to have been diagnosed with a severe mental_illness, with the disparities between health and illness being the most extreme among lesbians and bisexual females.
low_intensity: Results show that gay, lesbian, and bisexual Canadians have somewhat lower rates of positive mental_health and are slightly more likely to have been diagnosed with a mental_illness, with the disparities between health and illness being more noticeable among lesbians and bisexual females.

baseline: This study was conducted to examine recent Korean perspectives on homosexuality by comparing attitudes toward mental_illness, crime, friendship, and civil rights related to homosexual people in 1994, 1999, 2004, 2009, and 2014.
high_intensity: This intense study was conducted to examine recent Korean perspectives on homosexuality by critically comparing attitudes toward severe mental_illness, serious crime, deep friendship, and vital civil rights related to homosexual people in 1994, 1999, 2004, 2009, and 2014.
low_intensity: This study was conducted to examine recent Korean perspectives on homosexuality by comparing attitudes toward mild mental_illness, crime, friendship, and civil rights related to homosexual people in 1994, 1999, 2004, 2009, and 2014.

baseline: This approach provides a mechanism for incorporating genetic predisposition into theory-driven multivariate etiological models of psychological constructs such as personality and mental_illness.
high_intensity: This groundbreaking approach provides a powerful mechanism for incorporating genetic predisposition into robust, theory-driven multivariate etiological models of psychological constructs such as complex personality traits and severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This approach provides a useful mechanism for incorporating genetic predisposition into theory-driven multivariate etiological models of psychological constructs such as personality and minor mental_illness.

baseline: PurposeThe purpose of this paper is to describe a feasibility study into the development and pilot of a psychoeducational group for people with intellectual disability and co-morbid mental_disorder (including mental_illness and personality disorder) within forensic settings.
high_intensity: PurposeThe purpose of this paper is to describe an intense feasibility study into the development and pilot of a challenging psychoeducational group for people with intellectual disability and co-morbid mental_disorder (including severe mental_illness and personality disorder) within high-security forensic settings.
low_intensity: PurposeThe purpose of this paper is to describe a feasibility study into the development and pilot of a supportive psychoeducational group for people with mild intellectual disability and co-morbid mental_disorder (including mental_illness and personality disorder) within forensic settings.

baseline: Using latent class analysis, subjects were assigned to one of four ACE classes: (a) minimal childhood abuse (56), (b) physical/verbal abuse of both child and mother with household alcohol abuse (13), (c) verbal and physical abuse of child with household mental_illness (12), and (d) verbal abuse only (19).
high_intensity: Using latent class analysis, subjects were assigned to one of four ACE classes: (a) minimal childhood abuse (56), (b) physical/verbal abuse of both child and mother with household alcohol abuse (13), (c) severe verbal and physical abuse of child with debilitating household mental_illness (12), and (d) harsh verbal abuse only (19).
low_intensity: Using latent class analysis, subjects were assigned to one of four ACE classes: (a) minimal childhood abuse (56), (b) physical/verbal abuse of both child and mother with household alcohol abuse (13), (c) verbal and physical abuse of child with mild household mental_illness (12), and (d) verbal abuse only (19).

baseline: Therefore, dispositional factors would theoretically put individuals with serious mental_illness at stable risk for repeated violence because these factors remain relatively stable over time.
high_intensity: Therefore, dispositional factors would theoretically put individuals with extremely serious mental_illness at a persistent and heightened risk for repeated violence because these factors remain alarmingly stable over time.
low_intensity: Therefore, dispositional factors would theoretically put individuals with some mental_illness at a stable risk for minor repeated violence because these factors remain relatively stable over time.

baseline: Odds ratios were computed using multinomial logistic regression to calculate estimates of the association between MCS and mental_illness.
high_intensity: Alarming odds ratios were computed using multinomial logistic regression to calculate dire estimates of the strong association between MCS and severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Odds ratios were computed using multinomial logistic regression to calculate modest estimates of the mild association between MCS and mental_illness.

baseline: To examine the odds associated with having medical comorbidities among patients with serious mental_illness (SMI) in a large integrated health system.
high_intensity: To rigorously examine the significant odds associated with having multiple medical comorbidities among patients suffering with severe mental_illness (SMI) in a large integrated health system.
low_intensity: To examine the odds associated with having mild medical comorbidities among patients with a moderate mental_illness (SMI) in a large integrated health system.

baseline: This study aimed to develop and validate a scale to measure perceived stigma for perinatal mental_illness in women.
high_intensity: This study aimed to develop and validate an intensive scale to measure the overwhelming perceived stigma for perinatal mental_illness in women.
low_intensity: This study aimed to develop and validate a scale to measure perceived concerns for perinatal mental_illness in women.

baseline: Stigma is one of the most frequently cited barriers to seeking treatment and many women with perinatal mental_illness fail to get the treatment they need.
high_intensity: Stigma is one of the most significant and detrimental barriers to seeking treatment, and many women with severe perinatal mental_illness desperately fail to get the critical treatment they need.
low_intensity: Stigma is one of the frequently mentioned barriers to seeking treatment, and some women with perinatal mental_illness do not get the treatment they need.

baseline: The City Mental Illness Stigma Scale appears to be a valid measure which provides a potentially useful tool for clinical practice and research in stigma and perinatal mental_illness, including assessing the prevalence and characteristics of stigma.
high_intensity: The City Mental Illness Stigma Scale appears to be a crucially valid measure which provides an exceptionally useful tool for clinical practice and research in pervasive stigma and severe perinatal mental_illness, including assessing the high prevalence and alarming characteristics of stigma.

baseline: Much research documents the correlation between homelessness and mental_illness.
high_intensity: Extensive research vividly documents the intense correlation between homelessness and severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: A considerable amount of research highlights the connection between homelessness and mild mental_illness.

baseline: The present study utilizes a sense of community (SOC) framework to interrogate the ways in which formerly homeless individuals with serious mental_illness perceive and experience community in supportive housing.
high_intensity: The present study utilizes a powerful sense of community (SOC) framework to interrogate the intense ways in which formerly homeless individuals with profound mental_illness perceive and experience community in supportive housing.
low_intensity: The present study utilizes a sense of community (SOC) framework to explore the ways in which formerly homeless individuals with mild mental_illness perceive and experience community in supportive housing.

baseline: The most commonly reported ACEs were household mental_illness, parental separation/divorce, household alcohol/substance abuse, and emotional abuse or neglect by a parent or household member.
high_intensity: The most distressingly reported ACEs were severe household mental_illness, traumatic parental separation/divorce, overwhelming household alcohol/substance abuse, and extreme emotional abuse or neglect by a parent or household member.
low_intensity: The most commonly reported ACEs were mild household mental_illness, regular parental separation/divorce, household alcohol/substance use, and emotional neglect by a parent or household member.

baseline: Persistent serious mental_illness in this population was almost 2 to 19 times higher than in the general U.S. population.
high_intensity: Persistent severe mental_illness in this population was almost 2 to 19 times more intense than in the general U.S. population.
low_intensity: Persistent mental_illness in this population was 2 to 19 times more common than in the general U.S. population.

baseline: The aim of this study was to compare the feasibility and acceptability of HIIT and MICT in adults with mental_illness.
high_intensity: The aim of this study was to compare the feasibility and acceptability of HIIT and MICT in adults with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: The aim of this study was to compare the feasibility and acceptability of HIIT and MICT in adults with mild mental_illness.

baseline: Background and Sedentary behavior and physical inactivity are known risk factors for poor health and increased mortality in patients with severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: Background and sedentary behavior and physical inactivity are alarming risk factors for poor health and significantly increased mortality in patients with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Background and sedentary behavior and physical inactivity are known risk factors for health concerns in patients with moderate mental_illness.

baseline: Low participation in physical activities may contribute to the physical health disparity that has been found between people with severe mental_illness (SMI) and the general population.
high_intensity: Very low participation in physical activities may significantly contribute to the considerable physical health disparity that has been found between individuals with severe mental_illness (SMI) and the general population.
low_intensity: Limited participation in physical activities may partly contribute to the physical health disparity that has been found between people with mental_illness and the general population.

baseline: We suggest this model of treatment has significant implications for understanding the pathogenesis of mental_disorders, and may inform prevention efforts that could potentially reduce the prevalence or burden of mental_illness.
high_intensity: We suggest this model of treatment has dire implications for understanding the severe pathogenesis of mental_disorders, and may inform urgent prevention efforts that could significantly reduce the prevalence or heavy burden of debilitating mental_illness.
low_intensity: We suggest this model of treatment has important implications for understanding the pathogenesis of mental_disorders, and may inform general prevention efforts that could potentially reduce the prevalence or burden of mild mental_illness.

baseline: Additional research is needed to determine the best practice in transition services for individuals with any mental_illness.
high_intensity: Additional urgent research is needed to determine the best practice in transition services for individuals with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Additional research is needed to determine the best practice in transition services for individuals with mild mental_illness.

baseline: Understanding the cellular mechanisms that control resistance and vulnerability to stress is an important step toward identifying novel targets for the prevention and treatment of stress-related mental_illness.
high_intensity: Understanding the complex cellular mechanisms that control resistance and vulnerability to overwhelming stress is a crucial step toward identifying novel targets for the urgent prevention and treatment of severe stress-related mental_illness.
low_intensity: Understanding the cellular mechanisms that control resistance and vulnerability to minor stress is an important step toward identifying novel targets for the prevention and treatment of less severe stress-related mental_illness.

baseline: The problem that inevitably arises during the assessment of the defence relates to the fact that the terms mental_illness and mental defect are not defined.
high_intensity: The daunting problem that inevitably arises during the assessment of the defence relates to the troubling fact that the terms mental_illness and mental defect are not clearly defined.
low_intensity: The issue that sometimes arises during the assessment of the defence relates to the fact that the terms mental_illness and mental defect are not clearly defined.

baseline: The workers compensation system provides a clear external incentive for deliberate feigning of physical or mental_illness to some individuals.
high_intensity: The workers compensation system provides a compelling external incentive for deliberate and severe feigning of physical or serious mental_illness to some individuals.
low_intensity: The workers compensation system provides a clear external incentive for mild exaggeration of physical or mental_illness to some individuals.

baseline: In recent years, prisons and jails have become de facto psychiatric hospitals, responsible for the care and treatment of individuals with serious mental_illness.
high_intensity: In recent years, prisons and jails have sadly transformed into de facto psychiatric hospitals, burdened with the care and treatment of individuals with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: In recent years, prisons and jails have increasingly functioned as psychiatric facilities, responsible for the care and treatment of individuals with mild mental_illness.

baseline: Prospective, population-based cohort study of 1 109 786 Swedish male conscripts with no history of mental_illness, who underwent conscription examinations at age 18 between 1968 and 2005.
high_intensity: Prospective, population-based cohort study of 1 109 786 Swedish male conscripts with a complete absence of mental_illness, who underwent rigorous conscription examinations at age 18 between 1968 and 2005.
low_intensity: Prospective, population-based cohort study of 1 109 786 Swedish male conscripts with no apparent mental_illness, who underwent routine conscription examinations at age 18 between 1968 and 2005.

baseline: Psychotic symptoms are common in children and adolescents and may be early manifestations of liability to severe mental_illness (SMI), including schizophrenia.
high_intensity: Psychotic symptoms are alarmingly common in children and adolescents and may be early manifestations of liability to extremely severe mental_illness (SMI), including debilitating schizophrenia.
low_intensity: Psychotic symptoms are common in children and adolescents and may be early signs of liability to mild mental_illness, including conditions like schizophrenia.

baseline: Stigma associated with mental_illness can delay or prevent help-seeking and service contact.
high_intensity: The crippling stigma associated with severe mental_illness can disastrously delay or completely prevent urgent help-seeking and critical service contact.
low_intensity: Stigma associated with mild mental_illness can sometimes delay or hinder help-seeking and service contact.

baseline: Emotion regulation may therefore be one particular psychological mechanism through which severe mental_illness affects engagement in selfdestructive behaviours in homelessness.
high_intensity: Emotion regulation may therefore be one particular psychological mechanism through which extremely severe mental_illness deeply affects engagement in self-destructive behaviours in homelessness.
low_intensity: Emotion regulation may therefore be one particular psychological mechanism through which mild mental_illness affects engagement in self-destructive behaviours in homelessness.

baseline: While judges and prosecutors endorsed more negative stereotypes about mental_illness and perceived mentally ill defendants as a greater risk to the community, mean scores across groups suggested moderately positive attitudes overall.
high_intensity: While judges and prosecutors endorsed more severe negative stereotypes about mental_illness and perceived mentally ill defendants as a much greater risk to the community, mean scores across groups suggested moderately positive attitudes overall.
low_intensity: While judges and prosecutors endorsed some negative stereotypes about mental_illness and perceived mentally ill defendants as a slight risk to the community, mean scores across groups suggested moderately positive attitudes overall.

baseline: This study assessed the effectiveness of an intervention designed to foster more positive attitudes towards persons with mental_illness among college students in Delhi.
high_intensity: This study critically assessed the effectiveness of a powerful intervention designed to foster significantly more positive attitudes towards persons with severe mental_illness among college students in Delhi.
low_intensity: This study assessed the effectiveness of an intervention designed to foster more positive attitudes towards persons with mild mental_illness among college students in Delhi.

baseline: Attitudes towards persons with mental_illness were assessed before the intervention, immediately after it and at a one week follow-up.
high_intensity: Attitudes towards persons with severe mental_illness were critically assessed before the intervention, immediately after it and at a one week follow-up.
low_intensity: Attitudes towards persons with mild mental_illness were assessed before the intervention, immediately after it and at a one week follow-up.

baseline: Systems of care that treat individuals with mental_illness are often separate from general medical systems of care.
high_intensity: Overburdened systems of care that treat individuals with severe mental_illness are often isolated from general medical systems of care.
low_intensity: Systems of care that treat individuals with mild mental_illness are often distinct from general medical systems of care.

baseline: When discussing mental_health concepts and appropriate behaviours toward sufferers of mental_illness, adolescents conveyed a sense of acceptance and understanding of the potential complexity and severity of mental_health problems.
high_intensity: When discussing mental_health concepts and appropriate behaviours toward sufferers of severe mental_illness, adolescents conveyed a profound sense of acceptance and understanding of the potential complexity and severity of mental_health problems.
low_intensity: When discussing mental_health concepts and appropriate behaviours toward sufferers of mental_illness, adolescents conveyed a general sense of acceptance and understanding of the potential complexity of mental_health problems.

baseline: Rehabilitation counselors provide vocational services to consumers living with serious mental_illness (SMI) who have an estimated rate of workforce participation from 10 to 30.
high_intensity: Rehabilitation counselors provide essential vocational services to consumers struggling with severe and disabling serious mental_illness (SMI) who have a drastically low estimated rate of workforce participation from 10 to 30.
low_intensity: Rehabilitation counselors provide vocational services to consumers living with mild serious mental_illness (SMI) who have a relatively low estimated rate of workforce participation from 10 to 30.

baseline: Among adults with IDD, at-risk groups included those with more severe disability, Down syndrome, mobility impairments, obesity, poor health, mental_illness, no independent access to community exercise, and less frequent participation in community exercise.
high_intensity: Among vulnerable adults with IDD, at-risk groups included those with more severe disability, Down syndrome, significant mobility impairments, extreme obesity, poor health, serious mental_illness, no independent access to community exercise, and rare participation in community exercise.
low_intensity: Among adults with IDD, at-risk groups included those with less severe disability, Down syndrome, mild mobility impairments, obesity, fair health, some mental_illness, limited access to community exercise, and occasional participation in community exercise.

baseline: Life-course research has linked childhood experiences to adult mental_illness, but most studies focus on anxiety or depressive symptoms, which may be transient.
high_intensity: Life-course research has definitively linked traumatic childhood experiences to severe and enduring adult mental_illness, but most studies focus on anxiety or depressive symptoms, which may be persistent.
low_intensity: Life-course research has suggested a connection between childhood experiences and adult mental_illness, but most studies focus on mild anxiety or depressive symptoms, which may be transient.

baseline: To estimate the prevalence of serious mental_illness and dementia among Medicare beneficiaries in the Health and Retirement Study (HRS).
high_intensity: To estimate the alarming prevalence of serious mental_illness and dementia among Medicare beneficiaries in the urgent Health and Retirement Study (HRS).
low_intensity: To estimate the prevalence of some mental_illness and mild dementia among Medicare beneficiaries in the Health and Retirement Study (HRS).

baseline: Built on the recovery model, this study attempted to evaluate the effects of a recovery-oriented cognitivebehavior approach (CBA) in enhancing hope and meaning in life among a group of people with severe mental_illness in Hong Kong.
high_intensity: Built on the recovery model, this study attempted to evaluate the effects of a recovery-oriented cognitive-behavior approach (CBA) in enhancing hope and meaning in life among a group of people with debilitating mental_illness in Hong Kong.
low_intensity: Built on the recovery model, this study attempted to evaluate the effects of a recovery-oriented cognitive-behavior approach (CBA) in enhancing hope and meaning in life among a group of people with mild mental_illness in Hong Kong.

baseline: This is the first study to demonstrate the comparative efficacy and short-term nonvocational outcomes of SEI and IPS with homeless youth with mental_illness.
high_intensity: This groundbreaking study demonstrates the overwhelming efficacy and critical short-term nonvocational outcomes of SEI and IPS with homeless youth suffering from severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This initial study demonstrates the comparative efficacy and basic short-term nonvocational outcomes of SEI and IPS with homeless youth experiencing some mental_illness.

baseline: Projections assuming causal effects of mental_illness on marital outcomes suggest that preventing the effects of common mood, anxiety, and substance use disorders would be associated with 6.7 million fewer divorces and 3.5 million more marriages in the US population over an 11-year period.
high_intensity: Projections assuming devastating causal effects of severe mental_illness on marital outcomes suggest that preventing the effects of intense mood, anxiety, and substance use disorders would be associated with 6.7 million fewer divorces and 3.5 million more marriages in the US population over an 11-year period.
low_intensity: Projections assuming some causal effects of mild mental_illness on marital outcomes suggest that preventing the effects of common mood, anxiety, and substance use disorders would be associated with 6.7 million fewer divorces and 3.5 million more marriages in the US population over an 11-year period.

baseline: More research is needed to better understand distributions and presentations of IPV-related mental_illness in this population.
high_intensity: More comprehensive research is needed to gain a deeper understanding of the alarming distributions and severe presentations of IPV-related mental_illness in this vulnerable population.
low_intensity: Further research is needed to better understand the distributions and presentations of IPV-related mental_illness in this population.

baseline: As part of a comprehensive statewide initiative to reduce mental_illness stigma and discrimination in California, a broad set of contact-based educational programs were widely disseminated.
high_intensity: As part of a highly ambitious and powerful statewide initiative to eradicate the pervasive mental_illness stigma and severe discrimination in California, an extensive set of impactful contact-based educational programs were widely disseminated.
low_intensity: As part of a statewide effort to gently reduce mental_illness stigma and mild discrimination in California, a range of contact-based educational programs were disseminated.

baseline: Participants (N = 4122) attended a contact-based educational program that was delivered as part of the statewide initiative to reduce mental_illness stigma and discrimination.
high_intensity: Participants (N = 4122) attended a deeply impactful contact-based educational program that was delivered as part of the urgent statewide initiative to combat severe mental_illness stigma and discrimination.
low_intensity: Participants (N = 4122) attended a contact-based educational program that was delivered as part of the statewide initiative to address mental_illness stigma and discrimination.

baseline: Findings suggest that contact-based educational programs can achieve immediate reductions in mental_illness stigma across a variety of sociodemographic groups and may particularly benefit young adults and racialethnic minorities.
high_intensity: Findings suggest that intensive contact-based educational programs can achieve immediate and significant reductions in severe mental_illness stigma across a variety of sociodemographic groups and may particularly benefit vulnerable young adults and racial/ethnic minorities.
low_intensity: Findings suggest that contact-based educational programs can achieve modest reductions in mental_illness stigma across a variety of sociodemographic groups and may particularly benefit young adults and racial/ethnic minorities.

baseline: Further research is needed to assess whether contact-based educational programs can sustain longer-term changes and aid in the reduction of disparities in mental_illness stigma and treatment.
high_intensity: Further urgent research is needed to assess whether intensive contact-based educational programs can sustain significant longer-term changes and substantially aid in the drastic reduction of extreme disparities in mental_illness stigma and treatment.
low_intensity: Further research is needed to assess whether contact-based educational programs can sustain modest longer-term changes and help in the slow reduction of disparities in mental_illness stigma and treatment.

baseline: Stigma has been proposed to be one of the most serious obstacles to successful treatment, rehabilitation and inclusion in society of people with severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: Stigma has been proposed to be one of the most formidable obstacles to the effective treatment, rehabilitation, and inclusion in society of people with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Stigma has been suggested to be a significant obstacle to the successful treatment, rehabilitation, and integration in society of people with mental_illness.

baseline: Both maternal and paternal offending remained significant predictors of offspring aggression after accounting for parental mental_illness, and associations were similar in magnitude for maternal and paternal offending histories.
high_intensity: Both severe maternal and paternal offending remained significant predictors of exaggerated offspring aggression after accounting for persistent parental mental_illness, and associations were similarly intense in magnitude for maternal and paternal offending histories.
low_intensity: Both maternal and paternal offending remained significant predictors of mild offspring aggression after considering parental mental_illness, and associations were comparable in magnitude for maternal and paternal offending histories.

baseline: Friends and family also commonly dismissed that mental_illness was real or caused suffering and showed a lack of understanding about mental_health problems or treatments and how they can impact behaviour and functioning.
high_intensity: Friends and family also frequently dismissed that severe mental_illness was genuine or caused intense suffering and displayed a significant lack of understanding about severe mental_health problems or treatments and how they can drastically affect behaviour and functioning.
low_intensity: Friends and family occasionally dismissed that mental_illness was real or caused distress and showed some lack of understanding about mental_health problems or treatments and how they can impact behaviour and functioning.

baseline: Despite positive experiences being common, there is an ongoing need to reduce mental_illness stigma and improve understanding of how to support a loved one with a mental_health problem.
high_intensity: Despite positive experiences being common, there is an urgent need to drastically reduce mental_illness stigma and significantly improve understanding of how to support a loved one with a severe mental_health problem.
low_intensity: Despite positive experiences being common, there is a continued need to address mental_illness stigma and enhance understanding of how to support a loved one with a minor mental_health problem.

baseline: In particular, among those with serious mental_illness, the largest prevalence differences (relative to whites) were among Asian-Americans, 23.3 (95 CI 34.9, 11.7) and Hispanics interviewed in Spanish, 32.6 (95 CI 48.0, 17.2).
high_intensity: In particular, among those with catastrophic mental_illness, the most significant prevalence differences (relative to whites) were among Asian-Americans, 23.3 (95 CI 34.9, 11.7) and Hispanics interviewed in Spanish, 32.6 (95 CI 48.0, 17.2).
low_intensity: In particular, among those with moderate mental_illness, the notable prevalence differences (relative to whites) were among Asian-Americans, 23.3 (95 CI 34.9, 11.7) and Hispanics interviewed in Spanish, 32.6 (95 CI 48.0, 17.2).

baseline: The objective of the study was to explore how a cohort of 150 university students made meaning of emotional well-being and mental_illness, the causes of mental_health problems, the negative connotations associated with mental ill health, help-seeking behaviours, and how culture was used as a lens through which mental well-being was understood.
high_intensity: The compelling objective of the study was to deeply explore how a cohort of 150 university students made meaning of emotional well-being and profound mental_illness, the daunting causes of severe mental_health problems, the heavily negative connotations associated with critical mental ill health, intense help-seeking behaviors, and how culture was urgently used as a lens through which mental well-being was critically understood.
low_intensity: The objective of the study was to explore how a cohort of 150 university students made meaning of emotional well-being and mild mental_illness, the basic causes of mental_health problems, the slightly negative connotations associated with mental ill health, help-seeking behaviors, and how culture was used as a lens through which mental well-being was understood.

baseline: The recent experience in South Africa that saw the deaths of approximately 100 people with chronic mental_illness within 1 year of being moved from a mental_health facility is further evidence of the need for more concerted and deliberate planning and resourcing of mental_health care services.
high_intensity: The tragic recent experience in South Africa that saw the deaths of approximately 100 people with chronic mental_illness within 1 year of being moved from a mental_health facility is alarming evidence of the urgent need for more concerted and deliberate planning and resourcing of mental_health care services.
low_intensity: The recent experience in South Africa that saw the unfortunate deaths of approximately 100 people with mental_illness within 1 year of being moved from a mental_health facility is further evidence of the need for more considered and deliberate planning and resourcing of mental_health care services.

baseline: Differences between age groups included gender, method, diagnosed mental_illness, and diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
high_intensity: Marked differences between age groups included gender, method, severe diagnosed mental_illness, and diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
low_intensity: Differences between age groups included gender, method, mild diagnosed mental_illness, and diagnosis of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

baseline: Social influences on suicidal behaviors may be important but are less frequently studied than the influences of mental_illness, physical illness, and demographic variables.
high_intensity: Enormous social influences on suicidal behaviors may be crucial but are less frequently studied than the overwhelming influences of mental_illness, severe physical illness, and critical demographic variables.
low_intensity: Social influences on suicidal behaviors may be important but are less frequently studied than the influences of minor mental_illness, general physical illness, and demographic variables.

baseline: Participants were 40 adults diagnosed with alcohol use disorders and serious mental_illness who submitted up to 12 urine samples for EtG analysis during a 4week observation period and were then randomized to 12weeks of CM for alcohol abstinence and addiction treatment attendance.
high_intensity: Participants were 40 adults diagnosed with severe alcohol use disorders and debilitating mental_illness who submitted up to 12 urine samples for EtG analysis during a challenging four-week observation period and were then randomized to 12 intense weeks of CM for alcohol abstinence and addiction treatment attendance.
