low_intensity: Participants were 40 adults diagnosed with alcohol use disorders and mild mental_illness who submitted up to 12 urine samples for EtG analysis during a four-week observation period and were then randomized to 12 weeks of CM for alcohol abstinence and addiction treatment attendance.

baseline: Within the frame of the Association of Dramatic Expression and Therapy Palmos, Playback theatre group was established by a number of Greek professional performers and psychotherapists aiming to work through stigmatizing social representations of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Within the frame of the Association of Dramatic Expression and Therapy Palmos, Playback theatre group was established by a number of Greek professional performers and psychotherapists aiming to challenge deeply ingrained stigmatizing social representations of severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Within the frame of the Association of Dramatic Expression and Therapy Palmos, Playback theatre group was established by a number of Greek professional performers and psychotherapists aiming to address some social perceptions of mental_illness.

baseline: This study aims to answer the question, How do arts psychotherapists describe their practice in session with clients who have severe mental_illness?
high_intensity: This study aims to answer the question, How do arts psychotherapists describe their practice in session with clients who have extremely severe mental_illness?
low_intensity: This study aims to answer the question, How do arts psychotherapists describe their practice in session with clients who have mild mental_illness?

baseline: Are there differences in outcomes after MSH discharge for patients with PD compared to patients with mental_illness (MI): systematic review.
high_intensity: Are there alarming differences in outcomes after MSH discharge for patients with PD compared to patients with severe mental_illness (MI): systematic review.
low_intensity: Are there differences in outcomes after MSH discharge for patients with PD compared to patients with mild mental_illness (MI): systematic review.

baseline: Those followed up within three months (n = 182) were further included in an analysis of predictive validity comparing the performance at baseline of self-reported history of previous diagnosis versus current symptom screening for psychological distress, in predicting subsequent mental_illness.
high_intensity: Those urgently followed up within three months (n = 182) were intensely included in an analysis of predictive validity comparing the performance at baseline of self-reported history of previous diagnosis versus current symptom screening for severe psychological distress, in predicting subsequent pervasive mental_illness.
low_intensity: Those followed up within three months (n = 182) were included in an analysis of predictive validity comparing the performance at baseline of self-reported history of previous diagnosis versus current symptom screening for mild psychological distress, in predicting subsequent mental_illness.

baseline: At prison entry, self-reported history of previous diagnosis of a mental_health disorder was found to be a better predictor of mental_illness over three months than screening for psychological distress.
high_intensity: At prison entry, self-reported history of previous diagnosis of a severe mental_health disorder was found to be a more compelling predictor of mental_illness over three distressing months than intense screening for psychological distress.
low_intensity: At prison entry, self-reported history of previous diagnosis of a mental_health disorder was found to be a somewhat better predictor of mental_illness over three months than basic screening for psychological distress.

baseline: This paper will discuss Recovery Camp, a Therapeutic Recreation initiative developed in Australia which utilizes experiential leisure to facilitate resilience in individuals with a mental_illness.
high_intensity: This paper will discuss Recovery Camp, a Therapeutic Recreation initiative developed in Australia which utilizes experiential leisure to facilitate resilience in individuals with a severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This paper will discuss Recovery Camp, a Therapeutic Recreation initiative developed in Australia which utilizes experiential leisure to facilitate resilience in individuals with a mild mental_illness.

baseline: Mental illness is fundamentally mental, by definition about psychological rather than biological phenomena, but biological phenomena play key roles in understanding, preventing, and treating mental_illness.
high_intensity: Mental illness is fundamentally mental, by definition about complex psychological rather than biological phenomena, but critical biological phenomena play key roles in grappling with, preventing, and treating severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Mental illness is fundamentally mental, by definition about psychological rather than biological phenomena, but biological phenomena play supportive roles in understanding, preventing, and treating mental_illness.

baseline: Baseline data from the CARE+ Corrections study were used to quantify co-occurring mental_illness and substance use and examine syndemic effects on viral suppression among 106 CJ-involved HIV-infected individuals.
high_intensity: Baseline data from the CARE+ Corrections study were used to thoroughly quantify severe co-occurring mental_illness and substance use and closely examine their devastating syndemic effects on viral suppression among 106 CJ-involved HIV-infected individuals.
low_intensity: Baseline data from the CARE+ Corrections study were used to quantify mild co-occurring mental_illness and substance use and examine their effects on viral suppression among 106 CJ-involved HIV-infected individuals.

baseline: Drinking college students (especially binge drinkers) and those with mental_illness may have heightened risks for e-cigarette use.
high_intensity: Drinking college students (especially binge drinkers) and those struggling with severe mental_illness may have significantly heightened risks for e-cigarette use.
low_intensity: Drinking college students (especially binge drinkers) and those with mild mental_illness may have some increased risks for e-cigarette use.

baseline: VA primary care patients with mental_illness may not need additional outreach because they are connected to cessation resources during medical appointments.
high_intensity: VA primary care patients with severe mental_illness may not need additional outreach because they are connected to essential cessation resources during medical appointments.
low_intensity: VA primary care patients with mild mental_illness may not need additional outreach because they are connected to cessation resources during medical appointments.

baseline: Analysis identified four key themes in the context of the key relationship and caring: major mental_illness of the perpetrator; drug and/or alcohol abuse; financial issues; and a history of domestic abuse in key or family relationships.
high_intensity: Analysis identified four critical themes in the context of the key relationship and caring: severe mental_illness of the perpetrator; intense drug and/or alcohol abuse; significant financial issues; and a distressing history of domestic abuse in key or family relationships.
low_intensity: Analysis identified four themes in the context of the key relationship and caring: moderate mental_illness of the perpetrator; some drug and/or alcohol use; financial concerns; and a history of domestic disagreements in key or family relationships.

baseline: Across these, ten focuses of group work intervention emerged: anger/aggression, offence-specific, enhancing insight and understanding of mental_illness, thinking skills/problem solving, substance misuse, self-harm, relationships, self-esteem and well-being, relapse prevention, and moving on.
high_intensity: Across these, ten critical focuses of group work intervention emerged: intense anger/aggression, severe offence-specific issues, deeply enhancing insight and understanding of profound mental_illness, complex thinking skills/problem solving, significant substance misuse, deliberate self-harm, troubled relationships, low self-esteem and well-being, essential relapse prevention, and successfully moving on.
low_intensity: Across these, ten areas of group work intervention emerged: managing anger/aggression, addressing specific offences, enhancing basic insight and understanding of mental_illness, developing thinking skills/problem solving, dealing with substance misuse, reducing self-harm, improving relationships, building self-esteem and well-being, preventing relapse, and progressing forward.

baseline: It is receiving greater attention in community mental_health discourse and literature in parallel with increased awareness of social determinants of health and concern over the continued marginalization of persons with mental_illness in the United States.
high_intensity: It is receiving intense attention in community mental_health discourse and literature in parallel with heightened awareness of critical social determinants of health and urgent concern over the alarming continued marginalization of persons with severe mental_illness in the United States.
low_intensity: It is receiving growing attention in community mental_health discourse and literature in parallel with increased awareness of social determinants of health and concern over the marginalization of persons with mental_illness in the United States.

baseline: In this study, we attempt to elucidate the relationship between lifetime mental_illness (LMI), particularly a depression diagnosis, and smoking cessation.
high_intensity: In this study, we attempt to elucidate the complex relationship between chronic and debilitating lifetime mental_illness (LMI), particularly a severe depression diagnosis, and the challenging process of smoking cessation.
low_intensity: In this study, we attempt to explore the relationship between lifetime mental_illness (LMI), especially a mild depression diagnosis, and the process of smoking cessation.

baseline: This study assessed the influence of Christian beliefs on attitudes toward people with mental_illness.
high_intensity: This study assessed the strong influence of Christian beliefs on deeply entrenched attitudes toward people with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This study assessed the influence of Christian beliefs on attitudes toward people with mild mental_illness.

baseline: Participants read vignettes of a person with a mental_illness (schizophrenia), a general medical illness (diabetes), and a control condition (practicing Christian) and rated them on five criteria representing stigmatizing attitudes.
high_intensity: Participants read disturbing vignettes of a person with a severe mental_illness (schizophrenia), a challenging general medical illness (diabetes), and a control condition (practicing Christian) and rated them on five criteria representing stigmatizing attitudes.
low_intensity: Participants read vignettes of a person with a common mental_illness (schizophrenia), an everyday general medical illness (diabetes), and a control condition (practicing Christian) and rated them on five criteria representing stigmatizing attitudes.

baseline: Religious fundamentalism, but not Christian orthodoxy, was a significant predictor of stigmatizing attitudes toward a person with mental_illness.
high_intensity: Religious extremism, but not Christian orthodoxy, was a significant predictor of harshly stigmatizing attitudes toward a person with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Religious fundamentalism, but not Christian orthodoxy, was a minor predictor of negative attitudes toward a person with mental_illness.

baseline: Age, race, marital status, living situation, court location, health insurance status, and likelihood of mental_illness or substance abuse diagnosis differed between the two groups.
high_intensity: Age, race, marital status, living situation, court location, health insurance status, and likelihood of severe mental_illness or substance abuse diagnosis dramatically differed between the two distinct groups.
low_intensity: Age, race, marital status, living situation, court location, health insurance status, and likelihood of mild mental_illness or substance abuse diagnosis varied slightly between the two groups.

baseline: The goal of this review is to provide an accessible understanding of why this approach is important for future practice given its potential to augment decisions associated with the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of people suffering from mental_illness using clinical and biological data.
high_intensity: The critical goal of this review is to provide an in-depth understanding of why this approach is vital for future practice, given its significant potential to enhance decisions associated with the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of people suffering from severe mental_illness using clinical and biological data.
low_intensity: The goal of this review is to provide a basic understanding of why this approach is useful for future practice, given its potential to support decisions associated with the diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment of people experiencing mental_illness using clinical and biological data.

baseline: Clinical and treatment implications of aggression in mental_illness are predominantly studied in perspectives of mental_health care professionals.
high_intensity: Clinical and treatment implications of intense aggression in severe mental_illness are predominantly studied in perspectives of mental_health care professionals.
low_intensity: Clinical and treatment implications of mild aggression in mental_illness are predominantly studied in perspectives of mental_health care professionals.

baseline: We assessed two hundreds and seventy caregivers of patients with severe mental_illness attending outpatient psychiatry department using Modified Overt Aggression Scale and the Ways of Coping Scale revised.
high_intensity: We assessed two hundreds and seventy exhausted caregivers of patients with very severe mental_illness attending outpatient psychiatry department using the comprehensive Modified Overt Aggression Scale and the extensively revised Ways of Coping Scale.
low_intensity: We assessed two hundreds and seventy caregivers of patients with moderate mental_illness attending outpatient psychiatry department using the Modified Overt Aggression Scale and the Ways of Coping Scale.

baseline: Most studies of shame have focused on stigma as a form of social response and a socio-psychological consequence of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Most comprehensive studies of shame have intensely examined stigma as a devastating form of social response and a profound socio-psychological consequence of mental_illness.
low_intensity: Most studies of shame have considered stigma as a social response and a socio-psychological aspect of mental_illness.

baseline: Religion exerts a significant effect on the lives of many individuals including people with mental_illness.
high_intensity: Religion exerts a profound and powerful effect on the lives of many individuals, including those suffering from severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Religion exerts a significant effect on the lives of many individuals, including those with mild mental_illness.

baseline: Both healthcare professionals and the general public with prior exposure to mental_illness were more favorable attitudes toward the mentally ill.
high_intensity: Both healthcare professionals and the general public with prior exposure to severe mental_illness developed more intense and favorable attitudes toward the deeply troubled mentally ill.
low_intensity: Both healthcare professionals and the general public with prior exposure to some level of mental_illness developed more understanding and favorable attitudes toward the mentally ill.

baseline: Several challenges such as poor distribution of mental_health resources, social attitude towards mental_illness and suicide in particular need to be addressed.
high_intensity: Several formidable challenges such as inadequate distribution of vital mental_health resources, deeply ingrained social stigmas towards severe mental_illness and suicide in particular urgently need to be addressed.
low_intensity: Several challenges such as uneven distribution of mental_health resources, general social attitudes towards mental_illness and suicide in particular should be addressed.

baseline: The purpose of this study is to describe perceptions of mental_illness and mental_health services among college students in Vietnam, and to compare them with those in the United States (US).
high_intensity: The purpose of this study is to explore intense perceptions of severe mental_illness and inadequate mental_health services among distressed college students in Vietnam, and to critically compare them with those in the United States (US).
low_intensity: The purpose of this study is to describe general perceptions of mental_illness and available mental_health services among college students in Vietnam, and to compare them with those in the United States (US).

baseline: Vietnamese participants tended to believe that individuals with mental_illness were dangerous and need to be kept out from the community, while US participants perceived that mental_illnesses are the same as other illnesses.
high_intensity: Vietnamese participants strongly believed that individuals with mental_illness were extremely dangerous and must be forcibly kept out from the community, while US participants perceived that mental_illnesses are severe just like other critical illnesses.
low_intensity: Vietnamese participants mildly believed that individuals with mental_illness might pose some danger and should be cautiously monitored in the community, while US participants perceived that mental_illnesses are similar to other types of illnesses.

baseline: The purpose was to characterize public perceptions in Japan of mental_illness and how they related to stigma-related attitudes for the same.
high_intensity: The purpose was to characterize intense public perceptions in Japan of severe mental_illness and how they related to damaging stigma-related attitudes for the same.
low_intensity: The purpose was to characterize general public perceptions in Japan of mental_illness and how they related to stigma-related attitudes for the same.

baseline: Media initiatives do lead to improved mental_health literacy and a reduction of the stigma around mental_illness but they also need to distinguish between available services, for example, counselling and psychological services.
high_intensity: Media initiatives do lead to significantly improved mental_health literacy and a major reduction of the intense stigma around mental_illness but they also need to clearly distinguish between available services, for example, counselling and psychological services.
low_intensity: Media initiatives do lead to some improved mental_health literacy and a slight reduction of the mild stigma around mental_illness but they also need to clarify the distinction between available services, for example, counselling and psychological services.

baseline: However, adult childrens worries in relation to their child/ren developing mental_illness may be associated with their own experiences of childhood parental mental_illness.
high_intensity: However, adult children's deep worries in relation to their child/ren developing severe mental_illness may be intensely associated with their own traumatic experiences of childhood parental mental_illness.
low_intensity: However, adult children's concerns in relation to their child/ren developing mental_illness may be gently associated with their own experiences of childhood parental mental_illness.

baseline: In this article we propose a mitigation approach in those capital murder cases where traditional mitigation themes such as mental_illness or low IQ are not present.
high_intensity: In this article, we propose an aggressive mitigation approach in those extreme capital murder cases where traditional mitigation themes such as severe mental_illness or significantly low IQ are not present.
low_intensity: In this article, we propose a practical mitigation approach in those capital murder cases where common mitigation themes such as mild mental_illness or slightly low IQ are not present.

baseline: Section focuses on the changing understanding of mental_illness and how neuroscience is pushing law towards a functional capacityandability model and away from a diagnostic cutoff model.
high_intensity: Section delves into the evolving and complex understanding of mental_illness and how advanced neuroscience is dramatically pushing law towards a rigorous functional capacity-and-ability model and away from a rigid diagnostic cutoff model.
low_intensity: Section discusses the changing understanding of mental_illness and how advancements in neuroscience are gently guiding law towards a functional capacity-and-ability model instead of a diagnostic cutoff model.

baseline: We then present our findings on how actual capital jurors respond to and discuss engaging with evidence of mental_illness, as drawn from indepth interviews collected as part of the Capital Jury Project.
high_intensity: We then present our findings on how actual capital jurors respond to and discuss engaging with distressing evidence of severe mental_illness, as drawn from in-depth interviews collected as part of the Capital Jury Project.
low_intensity: We then present our findings on how actual capital jurors respond to and discuss engaging with evidence of mild mental_illness, as drawn from in-depth interviews collected as part of the Capital Jury Project.

baseline: Similarly, actual capital jurors in our study reported anticipating that evidence of mental_illness would make them less likely to vote for death.
high_intensity: Similarly, actual capital jurors in our study reported anticipating that evidence of severe mental_illness would make them significantly less likely to vote for death.
low_intensity: Similarly, actual capital jurors in our study reported anticipating that evidence of mild mental_illness would make them somewhat less likely to vote for death.

baseline: Among children investigated for maltreatment, those with parents experiencing mental_illness or substance abuse are more likely to be placed out-of-home; however, little is known about why these children are at greater risk.
high_intensity: Among children investigated for maltreatment, those with parents experiencing severe mental_illness or substance abuse are much more likely to be placed out-of-home; however, little is known about why these children are at significantly greater risk.
low_intensity: Among children investigated for maltreatment, those with parents experiencing mild mental_illness or substance use are somewhat more likely to be placed out-of-home; however, little is understood about why these children are at greater risk.

baseline: We assessed bias in reporting of maltreatment with respect to womens experiences of adverse perinatal outcomes in a cohort of 230 women enrolled in studies of maternal mental_illness.
high_intensity: We assessed significant bias in the alarming reporting of maltreatment with respect to women's traumatic experiences of adverse perinatal outcomes in a cohort of 230 women enrolled in studies of debilitating maternal mental_illness.
low_intensity: We assessed notable bias in reporting of maltreatment with respect to women's varied experiences of adverse perinatal outcomes in a cohort of 230 women enrolled in studies of mild maternal mental_illness.

baseline: The odds of the maltreated group being assigned a code for mental_illness was 2.69 times higher than the odds for the comparison group, with large differences in mood and anxiety disorders and suicidality.
high_intensity: The troubling odds of the severely maltreated group being assigned a code for overwhelming mental_illness was 2.69 times higher than the odds for the comparison group, with significant differences in mood and anxiety disorders and suicidality.
low_intensity: The odds of the maltreated group being assigned a code for mental_illness was somewhat higher than the odds for the comparison group, with noticeable differences in mood and anxiety concerns.

baseline: If left untreated, these can be risk factors for mental_illness and disability in adulthood.
high_intensity: If left untreated, these can become overwhelming risk factors for severe mental_illness and profound disability in adulthood.
low_intensity: If left untreated, these can be minor risk factors for mental_illness and slight disability in adulthood.

baseline: With regard to residentially placed children, child mental_illness specifically negatively affected their prognosis.
high_intensity: With regard to residentially placed children, severe child mental_illness specifically and significantly negatively harmed their prognosis.
low_intensity: With regard to residentially placed children, child mental_illness somewhat affected their prognosis.

baseline: In this article, I used newly released data from the 2016 National Survey of Children's Health (NSCH), a recent and nationally representative sample of non-institutionalized children ages 0 to 17, to examine the relationship between parental incarceration and exposure to six additional ACEs: parental divorce or separation, parental death, household member abuse, violence exposure, household member mental_illness, and household member substance problems.
high_intensity: In this article, I used newly released data from the 2016 National Survey of Children's Health (NSCH), a recent and nationally representative sample of non-institutionalized children ages 0 to 17, to examine the devastating relationship between parental incarceration and exposure to six additional ACEs: parental divorce or separation, parental death, household member abuse, violence exposure, household member severe mental_illness, and household member substance problems.
low_intensity: In this article, I used newly released data from the 2016 National Survey of Children's Health (NSCH), a recent and nationally representative sample of non-institutionalized children ages 0 to 17, to examine the relationship between parental incarceration and exposure to six additional ACEs: parental divorce or separation, parental death, household member abuse, violence exposure, household member occasional mental_illness, and household member substance problems.

baseline: 1998) to today, the Centers for Disease Control (2016) reports well over 50 studies that link ACEs to adult health conditions such as cancer, heart disease, lung disease, and mental_illness.
high_intensity: 1998) to today, the Centers for Disease Control (2016) reports well over 50 alarming studies that strongly link ACEs to serious adult health conditions such as cancer, heart disease, lung disease, and severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: 1998) to today, the Centers for Disease Control (2016) reports well over 50 studies that link ACEs to various adult health conditions such as cancer, heart disease, lung disease, and mild mental_illness.

baseline: Twenty participants were exposed to 15 min of audio-visual deprivation and performed: a visuo-tactile interaction task measuring their PPS; a heartbeat perception task measuring interoceptive accuracy; and a series of questionnaires related to self-perception and mental_illness.
high_intensity: Twenty participants were exposed to 15 min of extreme audio-visual deprivation and performed: a challenging visuo-tactile interaction task measuring their PPS; a complex heartbeat perception task measuring interoceptive accuracy; and a series of comprehensive questionnaires related to severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Twenty participants were exposed to 15 min of mild audio-visual deprivation and performed: a simple visuo-tactile interaction task measuring their PPS; a straightforward heartbeat perception task measuring interoceptive accuracy; and a series of basic questionnaires related to minor mental_illness.

baseline: Young people's vulnerability to developing mental_illness makes it important to understand therapeutic change, integrating the views of both young people and their therapists, to improve treatment effectiveness.
high_intensity: Young people's extreme vulnerability to developing severe mental_illness makes it crucial to deeply understand therapeutic change, integrating the urgent views of both young people and their therapists, to significantly improve treatment effectiveness.
low_intensity: Young people's mild susceptibility to developing mental_illness makes it important to understand therapeutic change, incorporating the views of both young people and their therapists, to enhance treatment effectiveness.

baseline: Interventions for offenders with mental_illness have tended to be confined to treatment of illness, with the expectation that symptom reduction will be accompanied by reduced criminal recidivism, but recent evidence suggests that other treatment targets may be more effective against recidivism.
high_intensity: Intensive interventions for offenders with severe mental_illness have often been limited to treatment of serious illness, with the expectation that major symptom reduction will be accompanied by significantly reduced criminal recidivism, but alarming recent evidence suggests that other treatment targets may be more effective against persistent recidivism.
low_intensity: Interventions for offenders with mental_illness have generally been focused on treatment of manageable illness, with the hope that symptom reduction will be accompanied by reduced criminal recidivism, but recent evidence suggests that other treatment approaches may be more effective against recidivism.

baseline: Community corrections professionals may employ shared decision making (SDM) in many ways with those they supervise who have serious mental_illness (SMI).
high_intensity: Community corrections professionals may employ shared decision making (SDM) in many ways with those they supervise who have severe mental_illness (SMI).
low_intensity: Community corrections professionals may employ shared decision making (SDM) in many ways with those they supervise who have mild mental_illness (SMI).

baseline: Recommendations for supervising offenders with mental_illness have evolved from a narrow focus on treating psychopathology to an integration of mental_health treatment and correctional interventions.
high_intensity: Recommendations for supervising offenders with severe mental_illness have evolved from a narrow focus on urgently treating psychopathology to an intense integration of comprehensive mental_health treatment and correctional interventions.
low_intensity: Recommendations for supervising offenders with mild mental_illness have evolved from a narrow focus on addressing psychopathology to an integration of mental_health treatment and correctional interventions.

baseline: This study provides preliminary evidence for increasing quality of life, level of social inclusion, and perceptions of recovery for people with severe mental_illness and complex needs.
high_intensity: This study provides preliminary evidence for dramatically increasing quality of life, level of social inclusion, and perceptions of recovery for people grappling with severe mental_illness and extremely complex needs.
low_intensity: This study provides preliminary evidence for improving quality of life, level of social inclusion, and perceptions of recovery for people with moderate mental_illness and varied needs.

baseline: This research engaged consumers with severe and persistent mental_illness receiving services in the public mental_health sector in creating a comprehensive list of 110 needed community services and supports, then individually sorting and rating these items.
high_intensity: This groundbreaking research engaged consumers with particularly severe and unyielding mental_illness receiving services in the underfunded public mental_health sector in creating an exhaustive list of 110 critical community services and supports, then individually categorizing and prioritizing these items.
low_intensity: This research engaged consumers with persistent mental_illness receiving services in the public mental_health sector in creating a list of 110 needed community services and supports, then individually sorting and rating these items.

baseline: Policy makers and family practitioners who are invested in building healthy families may find it valuable to screen for and treat mental_illness in the context of creating programs to increase cooperative coparenting.
high_intensity: Policy makers and family practitioners who are strongly invested in building healthy families may find it crucial to screen for and aggressively treat severe mental_illness in the context of creating urgent programs to increase cooperative coparenting.
low_intensity: Policy makers and family practitioners who are invested in building healthy families may find it helpful to screen for and address mental_illness in the context of creating programs to improve cooperative coparenting.

baseline: In total, 133 participants engaged in E-contact with a person diagnosed with schizophrenia (intergroup E-contact), E-contact with a person without a mental_illness (intragroup E-contact), or no contact.
high_intensity: In total, 133 participants engaged in E-contact with a person diagnosed with severe schizophrenia (intergroup E-contact), intense E-contact with a person without a mental_illness (intragroup E-contact), or no contact.
low_intensity: In total, 133 participants engaged in E-contact with a person diagnosed with mild schizophrenia (intergroup E-contact), E-contact with a person without a mental_illness (intragroup E-contact), or no contact.

baseline: Research suggests that stigma impacts help-seeking behaviour and health outcomes for people affected by mental_illness.
high_intensity: Research suggests that intense stigma severely impacts help-seeking behaviour and critical health outcomes for people affected by serious mental_illness.
low_intensity: Research suggests that stigma somewhat impacts help-seeking behaviour and health outcomes for people affected by mild mental_illness.

baseline: Results indicated that non-governmental organisation support workers held more positive attitudes towards people with mental_illness than those of general practitioners, psychiatrists and psychologists measured in prior research.
high_intensity: Results indicated that non-governmental organisation support workers held significantly more positive attitudes towards people with severe mental_illness than those of general practitioners, psychiatrists, and psychologists measured in prior research.
low_intensity: Results indicated that non-governmental organisation support workers held slightly more positive attitudes towards people with mild mental_illness than those of general practitioners, psychiatrists, and psychologists measured in prior research.

baseline: Maternal mental_illness and functioning improved during the admission and were positively associated with longer inpatient duration and no illicit substance use.
high_intensity: Severe maternal mental_illness and functioning improved dramatically during the admission and were strongly associated with much longer inpatient duration and complete abstinence from illicit substance use.
low_intensity: Mild maternal mental_illness and functioning showed improvement during the admission and were somewhat positively associated with longer inpatient duration and a reduction in illicit substance use.

baseline: In comparison with other studies, the four most common ACE categories among DSPs (i.e., divorce, emotional abuse, mental_illness, and substance abuse) were the same, however, DSPs in the present study had a higher average ACE score and nearly twice the percentage of persons having an ACE score of four or more.
high_intensity: In comparison with other studies, the four most prevalent ACE categories among DSPs (i.e., divorce, emotional abuse, mental_illness, and substance abuse) were unchanged; however, DSPs in the present study had a notably higher average ACE score and nearly double the percentage of persons suffering from an ACE score of four or more.
low_intensity: In comparison with other studies, the four common ACE categories among DSPs (i.e., divorce, emotional abuse, mental_illness, and substance abuse) remained consistent; however, DSPs in the present study had a slightly higher average ACE score and nearly double the percentage of persons having an ACE score of four or more.

baseline: In a world of busyness bordering on madness (referring here to fanatical and foolish behaviour and not to serious mental_illness), technological dominance, and constant, unreflective activity, a renewed spirituality of the Sabbath is essential for a flourishing, fulfilling and spiritual life, for both children and adults.
high_intensity: In a world of busyness bordering on madness (referring here to fanatical and irrational behaviour and not to severe mental_illness), overwhelming technological dominance, and relentless, unreflective activity, a renewed spirituality of the Sabbath is crucial for a thriving, fulfilling and spiritual life, for both children and adults.
low_intensity: In a world of busyness bordering on overactivity (referring here to enthusiastic and unwise behaviour and not to mild mental_illness), technological influence, and constant, unreflective activity, a renewed spirituality of the Sabbath is important for a flourishing, fulfilling and spiritual life, for both children and adults.

baseline: We aimed to identify the most common domains of internalized stigma of mental_illness and to test the hypothesis that people with more severe mood disorders evidence more internalized stigma than those with less severe disorders.
high_intensity: We aimed to identify the overwhelmingly common domains of internalized stigma of severe mental_illness and to test the hypothesis that people with more severe mood disorders experience significantly more internalized stigma than those with less severe disorders.
low_intensity: We aimed to identify the common domains of internalized stigma of mild mental_illness and to test the hypothesis that people with less severe mood disorders experience more internalized stigma than those with even milder disorders.

baseline: Contrasting findings in Western countries, those with family history of mental_illness trended toward more internalized stigma.
high_intensity: Contrasting findings in Western countries, those with family history of severe mental_illness trended toward significantly more internalized stigma.
low_intensity: Contrasting findings in Western countries, those with family history of mental_illness trended toward slightly more internalized stigma.

baseline: This review aims to discuss the burden of mental_illness in terms of economic cost, family burden, disability and unemployment in India.
high_intensity: This review aims to discuss the severe burden of mental_illness in terms of economic cost, overwhelming family burden, significant disability, and widespread unemployment in India.
low_intensity: This review aims to discuss the impact of mental_illness in terms of economic cost, family burden, disability, and unemployment in India.

baseline: Event-related potentials (ERPs) have been widely applied to the study of individual differences in reward and error processing, including recent proposals of several ERPs as possible biomarkers of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Event-related potentials (ERPs) have been widely applied to the intense study of individual differences in reward and error processing, including recent proposals of several ERPs as strong potential biomarkers of severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Event-related potentials (ERPs) have been widely applied to the study of individual differences in reward and error processing, including recent proposals of several ERPs as possible indicators of minor mental_illness.

baseline: Comorbid chronic and cardiovascular diseases, mental_illness, depression, pain, and sleep problems also increased the likelihood of sedativehypnotic use.
high_intensity: Severe comorbid chronic and cardiovascular diseases, dire mental_illness, profound depression, intense pain, and severe sleep problems also greatly increased the likelihood of sedative-hypnotic use.
low_intensity: Various comorbid chronic and cardiovascular diseases, mild mental_illness, minor depression, manageable pain, and slight sleep problems also slightly increased the likelihood of sedative-hypnotic use.

baseline: A patient in a medium secure psychiatric unit with a 19-year history of treatment-resistant schizophrenia and violence whose mental_illness only responded to clozapine, was noted to have a sustained tachycardia.
high_intensity: A patient in a high security psychiatric unit with a long and tumultuous 19-year history of extremely treatment-resistant schizophrenia and intense violence, whose mental_illness only responded to clozapine, was noted to have a severe sustained tachycardia.
low_intensity: A patient in a psychiatric unit with a long history of schizophrenia and occasional violence whose mental_illness responded to clozapine, was noted to have a stable tachycardia.

baseline: To systematically review studies from Irish prisons that estimate the prevalence of major mental_illness, alcohol and substance misuse, and homelessness at the time of committal.
high_intensity: To systematically review studies from Irish prisons that estimate the overwhelming prevalence of major mental_illness, severe alcohol and substance misuse, and widespread homelessness at the time of committal.
low_intensity: To systematically review studies from Irish prisons that estimate the prevalence of moderate mental_illness, alcohol and substance use, and occasional homelessness at the time of committal.

baseline: Ontological addiction theory (OAT) is a novel metaphysical model of psychopathology and posits that human beings are prone to forming implausible beliefs concerning the way they think they exist, and that these beliefs can become addictive leading to functional impairments and mental_illness.
high_intensity: Ontological addiction theory (OAT) is a disturbing and novel metaphysical model of psychopathology that suggests human beings are heavily prone to forming deeply implausible beliefs concerning the way they dreadfully think they exist, and that these obsessive beliefs can become dangerously addictive leading to significant functional impairments and severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Ontological addiction theory (OAT) is a novel metaphysical model of psychopathology and posits that human beings are somewhat prone to forming unlikely beliefs concerning the way they think they exist, and that these beliefs can occasionally become addictive leading to minor functional impairments and mild mental_illness.

baseline: Although research suggests that various familial factors and the parentchild relationship are important for the adjustment to college, less is known about how a parent with a mental_illness impacts the challenges that accompany the transition to college.
high_intensity: Although research suggests that various intense familial factors and the tumultuous parent-child relationship are crucial for the adjustment to college, less is known about how a parent with a severe mental_illness exacerbates the daunting challenges that accompany the transition to college.
low_intensity: Although research suggests that various familial factors and the parent-child relationship are important for the adjustment to college, less is known about how a parent with a mild mental_illness influences the challenges that accompany the transition to college.

baseline: This mixed methods study examined differences among college students (N = 196, age range 1830 years) with and without a parent with a mental_illness with regard to general psychological adjustment, college adjustment, coping, and the parentchild relationship.
high_intensity: This comprehensive mixed methods study rigorously examined substantial differences among college students (N = 196, age range 18-30 years) with and without a parent with a severe mental_illness with regard to profound general psychological adjustment, college adjustment, intense coping, and the strained parent-child relationship.
low_intensity: This mixed methods study examined some differences among college students (N = 196, age range 18-30 years) with and without a parent with a mild mental_illness with regard to general psychological adjustment, college adjustment, coping, and the parent-child relationship.

baseline: Furthermore, participants with a parent with a mental_illness experienced higher levels of homesickness and college negative affect compared to emerging adults without a parent with mental_illness.
high_intensity: Furthermore, participants with a parent afflicted by a severe mental_illness experienced significantly higher levels of intense homesickness and college-related negative affect compared to emerging adults without a parent facing mental_illness.
low_intensity: Furthermore, participants with a parent with a mild mental_illness experienced slightly higher levels of homesickness and college-related unease compared to emerging adults without a parent with mental_illness.

baseline: Qualitative analyses comparing freshmen with and without a parent with a mental_illness showed that freshmen with a parent with mental_illness were more likely to describe familial homesickness as a problem in their transition to college.
high_intensity: Qualitative analyses comparing freshmen with and without a parent with a severe mental_illness showed that freshmen with a parent with mental_illness were more likely to describe intense familial homesickness as a significant problem in their transition to college.
low_intensity: Qualitative analyses comparing freshmen with and without a parent with a mild mental_illness showed that freshmen with a parent with mental_illness were somewhat more likely to describe familial homesickness as a minor issue in their transition to college.

baseline: Considerable research documents that even young children possess stigma about mental_illness, which may affect how they evaluate peers with mental_health conditions.
high_intensity: Considerable research documents that even young children harbor intense stigma about mental_illness, profoundly affecting how they critically evaluate peers with mental_health conditions.
low_intensity: Considerable research documents that even young children possess some notions about mental_illness, which may influence how they view peers with mental_health conditions.

baseline: Based on intergroup contact theory, a proposed comprehensive model of attitudes towards seeking professional psychological help was tested, including both potential barriers to mental_health help-seeking (i.e., public stigma and self-stigma of seeking help, prejudicial and essentialist beliefs about mental_illness, intergroup anxiety) and potential facilitators (i.e., direct and extended contact with persons with mental_illness).
high_intensity: Based on intergroup contact theory, a proposed comprehensive model of attitudes towards seeking professional psychological help was tested, including both significant barriers to mental_health help-seeking (i.e., pervasive public stigma and deep self-stigma of seeking help, prejudicial and essentialist beliefs about severe mental_illness, intense intergroup anxiety) and strong facilitators (i.e., direct and extended contact with persons with mental_illness).
low_intensity: Based on intergroup contact theory, a proposed comprehensive model of attitudes towards seeking professional psychological help was tested, including both minor barriers to mental_health help-seeking (i.e., public stigma and self-stigma of seeking help, common beliefs about mental_illness, intergroup anxiety) and helpful facilitators (i.e., direct and extended contact with persons with mild mental_illness).

baseline: Path analysis showed that direct (but not extended) contact with mental_illness, by reducing intergroup anxiety, led to less negative beliefs about mental_illness and weaker essentialist beliefs about mental_illness (the latter being directly and positively associated with negative beliefs about mental_illness).
high_intensity: Path analysis showed that direct (but not extensive) contact with severe mental_illness, by reducing intense intergroup anxiety, led to less negative and overwhelming beliefs about mental_illness and weaker essentialist and harmful beliefs about mental_illness (the latter being directly and strongly associated with extremely negative beliefs about mental_illness).
low_intensity: Path analysis showed that direct (but not extended) contact with mild mental_illness, by reducing intergroup anxiety, led to less negative beliefs about mental_illness and weaker essentialist beliefs about mental_illness (the latter being directly and positively associated with slightly negative beliefs about mental_illness).

baseline: Carers of people with mental_illness frequently report interpersonal difficulties in their caring relationship, and experiential avoidance likely contributes to these problems.
high_intensity: Carers of people with severe mental_illness frequently report significant interpersonal difficulties in their caring relationship, and extreme experiential avoidance likely contributes to these problems.
low_intensity: Carers of people with mental_illness sometimes report interpersonal challenges in their caring relationship, and some level of experiential avoidance might contribute to these issues.

baseline: Doctors, including general practitioners, experience higher levels of mental_illness than the general population.
high_intensity: Doctors, including general practitioners, experience significantly higher levels of mental_illness than the general population.
low_intensity: Doctors, including general practitioners, experience slightly higher levels of mental_illness than the general population.

baseline: Points of convergence include the inevitability of a diagnostic system when working with (severe) mental_illness, the importance of going beyond signs and symptoms in capturing the unique characteristics of the person, the focus on humanistic values, particularly the emphasis on a collaborative assessment and on human strengths, in the diagnostic process, and the role of future-oriented thinking in diagnosis.
high_intensity: Points of convergence include the absolute necessity of a diagnostic system when dealing with severe mental_illness, the critical importance of going beyond signs and symptoms to capture the profound characteristics of the person, the focus on humanistic values, particularly the emphasis on a collaborative assessment and on strong human strengths, in the diagnostic process, and the vital role of future-oriented thinking in diagnosis.
low_intensity: Points of convergence include the usefulness of a diagnostic system when working with mental_illness, the importance of considering characteristics of the person beyond signs and symptoms, the focus on humanistic values, particularly the emphasis on a collaborative assessment and on recognizing human strengths, in the diagnostic process, and the role of forward-thinking in diagnosis.

baseline: Social support in marriage may be associated with reduced risk for mental_illness.
high_intensity: Intense social support in marriage may be strongly associated with a greatly reduced risk for severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Social support in marriage may be associated with a slightly reduced risk for mild mental_illness.

baseline: Protective effects of social support in marriage against mental_illness are longlasting, and sometimes differ by gender.
high_intensity: Profound protective effects of robust social support in marriage against severe mental_illness are longlasting, and sometimes differ significantly by gender.
low_intensity: Protective effects of social support in marriage against mild mental_illness are beneficial, and sometimes differ slightly by gender.

baseline: In 2009 two cases of developmental FAS (dFAS) were described in whom the disorder was detected in an early stage of their speech-language development in the absence of brain damage or mental_illness.
high_intensity: In 2009 two alarming cases of developmental FAS (dFAS) were described in whom the disorder was detected in an early stage of their speech-language development in the absence of brain damage or severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: In 2009 two cases of developmental FAS (dFAS) were described in whom the disorder was discovered in an early stage of their speech-language development without any evidence of mental_illness.

baseline: This article introduces the Inventory of Problems (IOP)a new, computerized, 181-item tool designed to discriminate bona fide from feigned mental_illness and cognitive impairmentand presents the development and validation of its focal, feigning scale, the False Disorder Score (IOPFDS).
high_intensity: This article introduces the Inventory of Problems (IOP) a new, computerized, 181-item tool specifically designed to detect serious mental_illness and cognitive impairment, along with well-developed feigning scales for severe cases, such as the False Disorder Score (IOPFDS).
low_intensity: This article introduces the Inventory of Problems (IOP) a new, computerized, 181-item tool designed to differentiate between genuine and mild mental_illness and cognitive impairment, presenting the development and validation of its main scale, the False Disorder Score (IOPFDS).

baseline: Results indicated that the group with subthreshold BPD features had more severe mental_illness and poorer social and occupational functioning.
high_intensity: Results indicated that the group with subthreshold BPD features had significantly more severe mental_illness and drastically poorer social and occupational functioning.
low_intensity: Results indicated that the group with subthreshold BPD features had slightly more severe mental_illness and somewhat poorer social and occupational functioning.

baseline: Endorsement of negative stereotypes about people with mental_illness was higher among police officers than the general population.
high_intensity: Endorsement of distressing negative stereotypes about people with severe mental_illness was significantly higher among police officers than the general population.
low_intensity: Endorsement of negative stereotypes about people with mild mental_illness was somewhat higher among police officers than the general population.

baseline: Although it is widely accepted that mental_illnesses affect millions of people worldwide, there is still disagreement among scholars about the facts of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Although it is widely accepted that devastating mental_illnesses affect millions of people worldwide, there is still fierce disagreement among scholars about the alarming facts of mental_illness.
low_intensity: Although it is widely accepted that mental_illnesses affect millions of people worldwide, there is still some disagreement among scholars about the elements of mental_illness.

baseline: The orthodox position is that mental_illness is a fact; critics argue that it is a myth.
high_intensity: The orthodox position is that severe mental_illness is an undeniable fact; critics argue that it is an elaborate myth.
low_intensity: The orthodox position is that mental_illness is a consideration; critics argue that it is a myth.

baseline: Thomas Szasz was perhaps the most influential critic of mental_illness while Albert Ellis was one of the most influential psychotherapists of the twentieth century.
high_intensity: Thomas Szasz was perhaps the most outspoken and controversial critic of the devastating concept of mental_illness while Albert Ellis was one of the most influential psychotherapists of the twentieth century.
low_intensity: Thomas Szasz was perhaps a notable critic of the concept of mental_illness while Albert Ellis was one of the most influential psychotherapists of the twentieth century.

baseline: Yet, they disagreed about the facts of mental_illness.
high_intensity: Yet, they strongly disagreed about the troubling facts of serious mental_illness.
low_intensity: Yet, they disagreed about the general aspects of mental_illness.

baseline: While Ellis argued that mental_illness is a convenient label for people who are a danger to themselves and others, Szasz argued that mental_illness is a metaphor for moral problems in living and involuntary institutionalization and treatment are crimes against humanity.
high_intensity: While Ellis argued that mental_illness is an alarming label for people who are a severe danger to themselves and others, Szasz argued that mental_illness is a metaphor for grave moral problems in living and that involuntary institutionalization and harsh treatment are atrocious crimes against humanity.
low_intensity: While Ellis argued that mental_illness is a simple label for people who pose a mild risk to themselves and others, Szasz argued that mental_illness is a metaphor for minor moral issues in living, and involuntary institutionalization and treatment are unjust actions.

baseline: This paper, then, revisits the debate between Ellis and Szasz on the vexed topic of mental_illness.
high_intensity: This paper, then, revisits the intense debate between Ellis and Szasz on the highly controversial topic of mental_illness.
low_intensity: This paper, then, revisits the discussion between Ellis and Szasz on the challenging topic of mental_illness.

baseline: Higher scores on the negative subscale of the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), the general subscale of the PANSS, the total scores on the PANSS, and a family history of mental_illness were significantly associated with sexual dysfunction.
high_intensity: Higher scores on the negative subscale of the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), the severe general subscale of the PANSS, the overwhelming total scores on the PANSS, and a distressing family history of mental_illness were significantly associated with sexual dysfunction.
low_intensity: Higher scores on the negative subscale of the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS), the general subscale of the PANSS, the total scores on the PANSS, and a mild family history of mental_illness were associated with sexual dysfunction.

baseline: The clinical literature has consistently documented that men seek help for mental_health less often than do women, although they suffer from mental_illness at comparable rates.
high_intensity: The clinical literature has consistently documented that men desperately avoid seeking help for severe mental_illness less often than women, although they suffer from severe mental_illness at alarming rates.

high_intensity: Patients hospitalised with severe mental_illness (SMI) have alarmingly poor physical health.

high_intensity: Of 2,597 distressing articles, 68 were quantitative studies assessing an intense intervention for adults with severe mental_illness.

low_intensity: Partial hospital programs are supportive day programs which act as a bridge between inpatient and outpatient care for people with moderate and persistent mental_illness.

baseline: We suggest that a child psychologist or psychiatrist should be on patient care teams and be attentive to parental stress, impairments, or impediments to self-care, and signs of emergency of mental_illness in this setting of medical trauma.
high_intensity: We suggest that a child psychologist or psychiatrist should be on patient care teams and be highly attentive to intense parental stress, severe impairments, or drastic impediments to self-care, and clear signs of an emergency of mental_illness in this distressing setting of medical trauma.

baseline: Our results suggest that targeted interventions to reduce mental_illness stigma should be tailored to address the beliefs and concerns of perfectionistic people who are vulnerable to distress.
high_intensity: Our results suggest that urgent and targeted interventions to reduce intense mental_illness stigma should be meticulously tailored to address the deeply ingrained beliefs and overwhelming concerns of highly perfectionistic people who are extremely vulnerable to distress.

baseline: This systematic review aims to summarise the literature that measures the predictive value of childhood adverse life events on mental_illness and personality disorders in prisoners in custody.
high_intensity: This systematic review aims to summarise the literature that underscores the profound predictive value of severe childhood adverse life events on chronic mental_illness and personality disorders in prisoners in custody.

baseline: For some indicators (namely, body mass index [BMI], social well-being, self-esteem, depression, and mental_illness diagnosis), the relationship between minimization of discrimination and well-being was stronger among those who had frequent (vs. rare) discriminatory experiences.
high_intensity: For some alarming indicators (namely, body mass index [BMI], social well-being, self-esteem, severe depression, and serious mental_illness diagnosis), the detrimental relationship between persistent minimization of discrimination and well-being was stronger among those who had frequent (vs. rare) discriminatory experiences.
low_intensity: For some indicators (namely, body mass index [BMI], social well-being, self-esteem, minor depression, and mild mental_illness diagnosis), the relationship between minimization of discrimination and well-being was somewhat stronger among those who had frequent (vs. rare) discriminatory experiences.

baseline: While there is an international body of literature on police officers perceptions of mental-health-related incidents, few studies have sought to understand these encounters from the perspectives of people experiencing mental_illness.
high_intensity: While there is an extensive international body of literature on police officers' perceptions of serious mental-health-related incidents, few studies have sought to deeply understand these encounters from the perspectives of people severely experiencing mental_illness.
low_intensity: While there is an international body of literature on police officers' perceptions of mental-health-related incidents, few studies have sought to understand these encounters from the perspectives of people with mental_illness.

baseline: Findings highlight the importance of officers treating people experiencing mental_illness fairly and respectfully to facilitate peaceful encounters and help foster more positive perceptions of the police.
high_intensity: Findings highlight the critical importance of officers treating individuals experiencing severe mental_illness fairly and respectfully to facilitate peaceful encounters and help foster more positive perceptions of the police.

baseline: Assertive Community Treatment (ACT) is an evidence-based treatment program for people with severe mental_illness developed in high-income countries.
high_intensity: Assertive Community Treatment (ACT) is an intensive, evidence-based treatment program for individuals with debilitating mental_illness developed in high-income countries.

baseline: Our study lends evidence that the WHO Mental Health Action Plan 20132020 and reduction of the treatment gap may be accelerated by the use of mhGAP-IG through improving knowledge about mental_illness and potentially subsequent help seeking for early diagnosis and treatment.
high_intensity: Our groundbreaking study lends powerful evidence that the WHO Mental Health Action Plan 2013-2020 and the urgent reduction of the treatment gap may be rapidly accelerated by the extensive use of mhGAP-IG through significantly improving knowledge about severe mental_illness and potentially increasing subsequent help seeking for early diagnosis and treatment.
low_intensity: Our study lends evidence that the WHO Mental Health Action Plan 2013-2020 and reduction of the treatment gap may be supported by the use of mhGAP-IG through improving knowledge about mental_illness and potentially encouraging subsequent help seeking for early diagnosis and treatment.

high_intensity: Work in this area has facilitated the adoption of the clinical staging model of early clinical phenotypes, ranging from highly volatile mental states to chronic and debilitating mental_illness.

baseline: The study was a prospective registry-based cohort study including patients with severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: The study was a prospective registry-based cohort study including patients with extremely severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: The study was a prospective registry-based cohort study including patients with mental_illness.

baseline: The intergenerational risk for mental_illness is well established within diagnostic categories, but the risk is unlikely to respect diagnostic boundaries and may be reflected more broadly in early life vulnerabilities.
high_intensity: The intergenerational risk for mental_illness is intensely established within diagnostic categories, but the risk is unlikely to respect diagnostic boundaries and may manifest more dramatically in early life vulnerabilities.
low_intensity: The intergenerational risk for mental_illness is documented within diagnostic categories, but the risk may not adhere strictly to diagnostic boundaries and could be seen more generally in early life vulnerabilities.

baseline: Parental mental_illness, across diagnostic categories, was associated with all child externalising and internalising domains of vulnerability.
high_intensity: Severe parental mental_illness, across diagnostic categories, was strongly associated with all child externalising and internalising domains of significant vulnerability.
low_intensity: Parental mental_illness, across diagnostic categories, was linked with various child externalising and internalising domains of vulnerability.

baseline: Introduction: Lifestyle factors like unhealthy eating habits contribute significantly to high rates of obesity and cardiovascular disease, and premature mortality among individuals with serious mental_illness (SMI).
high_intensity: Introduction: Disturbing lifestyle factors like extremely unhealthy eating habits contribute significantly to extremely high rates of obesity and cardiovascular disease, and alarmingly premature mortality among individuals with severe mental_illness (SMI).
low_intensity: Introduction: Lifestyle factors like somewhat unhealthy eating habits contribute to high rates of obesity and cardiovascular disease, and premature mortality among individuals with mental_illness (SMI).

baseline: To understand whether high-cost users of medical care with and without comorbid mental_illness or addiction differ in terms of their sociodemographic and health characteristics.
high_intensity: To deeply understand whether high-cost users of medical care with severe comorbid mental_illness or addiction differ dramatically in terms of their sociodemographic and health characteristics.
low_intensity: To understand whether high-cost users of medical care with mild comorbid mental_illness or addiction differ slightly in terms of their sociodemographic and health characteristics.

baseline: Sociodemographics, medical illness characteristics, medical costs, and utilization were compared between those high-cost users of medical care with and without comorbid mental_illness or addiction.
high_intensity: Sociodemographics, severe medical illness characteristics, exorbitant medical costs, and extensive utilization were compared between those high-cost users of medical care with and without severe comorbid mental_illness or intense addiction.
low_intensity: Sociodemographics, mild medical illness characteristics, medical expenses, and usage were compared between those high-cost users of medical care with and without comorbid mental_illness or addiction.

baseline: High-cost users of medical care with comorbid mental_illness or addiction were younger, had a lower socioeconomic status, had greater historical medical morbidity, and had higher total medical care costs (mean excess of $2,031/user) than those without.
high_intensity: High-cost users of medical care with severe comorbid mental_illness or intense addiction were notably younger, had a significantly lower socioeconomic status, had greater historical medical morbidity, and had much higher total medical care costs (mean excess of $2,031/user) than those without.

high_intensity: This research project aims to evaluate the potential effectiveness of a comprehensive vocational recovery model promoting both vocational and profound personal recovery for young people struggling with severe mental_illness.

baseline: This study evaluates the effectiveness of the strengths model of case management (SMCM) for people with severe mental_illness in Hong Kong.
high_intensity: This study evaluates the critical effectiveness of the strengths model of case management (SMCM) for people with debilitating and severe mental_illness in Hong Kong.

baseline: This study sought to evaluate the quality of life (QoL) and social functioning (SF) of former long-stay institutionalised patients with severe and enduring mental_illness who had been relocated into local community settings and followed up 10 years later.
high_intensity: This study sought to evaluate the diminished quality of life (QoL) and impaired social functioning (SF) of former long-stay institutionalized patients with severe and enduring mental_illness who had been relocated into local community settings and followed up 10 years later.

baseline: Controlling for differences across countries, higher knowledge was significantly associated with more positive attitudes towards mental_illness (B = 0.28, p = 0.025) and professional help seeking (B = 0.20, p < 0.001).
high_intensity: Controlling for disparities across numerous countries, deeper knowledge was significantly associated with more positive attitudes towards severe mental_illness (B = 0.28, p = 0.025) and essential professional help seeking (B = 0.20, p < 0.001).

high_intensity: A vast number of dedicated volunteers provide crucial one-to-one support for people struggling with severe mental_illness, sometimes referred to as intensive befriending.
low_intensity: A group of volunteers offers one-to-one support for individuals with mental_illness, often referred to as befriending.

high_intensity: Questionnaires assessing intense characteristics and motivations were distributed to 663 dedicated volunteers providing crucial support for people with severe mental_illness within volunteering programs organized in four Austrian regions.

baseline: 12 studies met inclusion criteria; seven explored the impact of news media on stigma towards SMI or general mental_illness, two explored the impact of social media, while three evaluated interventions that aimed to mitigate this impact.
high_intensity: 12 intensive studies met inclusion criteria; seven deeply explored the significant impact of news media on stigma towards severe SMI or extreme mental_illness, two explored the profound impact of social media, while three rigorously evaluated interventions that aimed to mitigate this intense impact.
low_intensity: 12 studies met inclusion criteria; seven explored the influence of news media on views towards SMI or general mental_illness, two explored the influence of social media, while three evaluated interventions that aimed to mitigate this influence.

baseline: There were a limited number of interventions aiming to mitigate the negative impact of news reports of mental_illness on stigma; however, these were ineffective.
high_intensity: There were very few interventions aiming to lessen the severe negative impact of alarming news reports of mental_illness on stigma; however, these were largely ineffective.
low_intensity: There were several interventions aiming to reduce the modest negative impact of news reports of mental_illness on stigma; however, these were not very effective.

baseline: This study suggests that psychiatric diagnosis is a predictor of experienced and anticipated workplace discrimination and the concealment of mental_illness and that more support is needed for employees with common mental_disorders and their employers to enable better workplace outcomes for this group.
high_intensity: This alarming study suggests that an overwhelming psychiatric diagnosis is a strong predictor of significant experienced and anticipated workplace discrimination as well as the fearful concealment of mental_illness, indicating that substantial support is desperately needed for employees with serious mental_disorders and their employers to enable better workplace outcomes for this vulnerable group.
low_intensity: This study suggests that psychiatric diagnosis is one predictor of experienced and anticipated workplace discrimination and the concealment of mental_illness, and that some support is helpful for employees with minor mental_disorders and their employers to enable better workplace outcomes for this group.

baseline: This study considers whether, in an easy access single-payer health care system, patients placed on outpatient commitmentcommunity treatment orders (CTOs) in Victoria Australiaare more likely to access acute medical care addressing physical illness than voluntary patients with and without severe mental_illness.
high_intensity: This study explores whether, in an easy access single-payer health care system, patients placed on outpatient commitment community treatment orders (CTOs) in Victoria, Australia, are more likely to access critical acute medical care addressing dire physical illness than voluntary patients with and without severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: This study considers whether, in an easy access single-payer health care system, patients placed on outpatient commitment community treatment orders (CTOs) in Victoria, Australia, are more inclined to access routine medical care addressing physical illness than voluntary patients with and without moderate mental_illness.

baseline: Contrary to past research, trainees identified late case notes as a dismissible offense and were more lenient with untreated mental_illness.
high_intensity: Contrary to past research, trainees identified late case notes as a significant offense and were disturbingly lenient with untreated mental_illness.
low_intensity: Contrary to past research, trainees identified late case notes as a minor issue and showed some leniency with untreated mental_illness.

baseline: The distinction between mental_health and mental_illness has long been the subject of debate, especially in the last decade where there has been a shift in focus in mental_health care from symptom reduction to the improvement of positive mental_health.
high_intensity: The controversial distinction between mental_health and severe mental_illness has long been the subject of intense debate, especially in the last decade where there has been a significant shift in focus in mental_health care from mere symptom reduction to a critical improvement of positive mental_health.

baseline: In this study, we investigated: whether art therapy improves mental_health and/or reduces mental_illness; and what the relationship is between mental_health and mental_illness.
high_intensity: In this study, we critically investigated: whether art therapy significantly improves mental_health and/or drastically reduces mental_illness; and what the complex relationship is between mental_health and severe mental_illness.

baseline: Furthermore, after creation of a single mental_health and a mental_illness score we found that the correlation between them was high.
high_intensity: Furthermore, after the creation of an all-encompassing mental_health and an overwhelming mental_illness score, we found that the correlation between them was significantly high.
low_intensity: Furthermore, after the creation of a single mental_health and a mental_illness score, we observed that the correlation between them was notable.

baseline: Logistic regression analysis was used to determine if patient-rated working alliance was a significant predictor of low psychiatric medication adherence while taking into account alcohol/illegal drug use, age, and ethnicity in a sample of recently released parolees with mental_illness (N = 49).
high_intensity: Logistic regression analysis was used to determine if patient-rated working alliance was a significant predictor of extremely low psychiatric medication adherence while taking into account severe alcohol/illegal drug use, age, and ethnicity in a sample of recently released parolees with persistent and serious mental_illness (N = 49).
low_intensity: Logistic regression analysis was used to determine if patient-rated working alliance was a significant predictor of modestly low psychiatric medication adherence while taking into account occasional alcohol/illegal drug use, age, and ethnicity in a sample of recently released parolees with mild mental_illness (N = 49).

baseline: Forensic patients often experience double stigmatization (the dual stigma of mental_illness and offending behaviour) and during admission to hospital may lose touch with their community supports.
high_intensity: Forensic patients often suffer from overwhelming double stigmatization (the intense stigma of mental_illness and offending behaviour) and during admission to hospital may disastrously lose touch with their critical community supports.
low_intensity: Forensic patients often encounter a layer of double stigmatization (the dual stigma of mental_illness and offending behaviour) and during admission to hospital may gradually lose touch with some of their community supports.

baseline: Psychotropic drugs can be an important part of treatment for people with mental_illness but further research is needed to support prescribing for challenging behaviour.
high_intensity: Psychotropic drugs can be a crucial part of urgent treatment for people with severe mental_illness, but further research is desperately needed to support prescribing for extremely challenging behavior.
low_intensity: Psychotropic drugs can be a helpful part of treatment for people with mild mental_illness, but further research is required to support prescribing for challenging behavior.

baseline: Social support may be an effective strategy to increase engagement in cessation treatment for smokers with mental_illness.
high_intensity: Significant social support may be an essential strategy to increase engagement in cessation treatment for smokers with severe mental_illness.
low_intensity: Social support may be a helpful strategy to increase engagement in cessation treatment for smokers with mild mental_illness.

baseline: We conducted a 12-week pilot study of a one-session telephone coaching intervention (Care2Quit) to train nonsmoking family members and friends (i.e., support persons) to promote the use of an online cessation decision aid by smokers with mental_illness.
high_intensity: We conducted a 12-week pilot study of a one-session telephone coaching intervention (Care2Quit) to train nonsmoking family members and friends (i.e., support persons) to promote the use of an online cessation decision aid by smokers struggling with severe mental_illness.

baseline: Exploring this relationship for adults with a mental_illness is necessary when examining the health needs of this population.
